B00OPZJDO0	These used to be "Great Inexpensive Riding Underwear Helped Me Enjoy Riding My Bike Again!" But not so much now, read on... After a few uses and runs through the washing machine, they're still holding up really well with no signs of wear yet. I'll be purchasing more of these.Civic/Consumer Duty Updated Review: Because I liked my original purchase of these riding underwear so much, I left a very favorable review when I purchased a second pair from the same seller and listing based off of my prior purchase. I expected to get the same product. No! The current purchase only slightly resembled the original purchase. The material and padding seems to be the same, but the differences with the recently received package are a very small waist band, elastics leg bands added, and no side support stretch stitching.There's enough of a difference in my comfort and ride now that I will look elsewhere when I need to purchase a new pair. I'll attach photos that I'm sure will be helpful. Know that the original pair I like better is the one with the large waist band and grey side stitching. If you look closely at the photos, you can see the stitching on the newer pair is of much higher quality too. Also, the photo may make the padding look like it's concave, but it is actually convex on both pairs. Please also know that the older pair has been used several times (held up very well) and the newer pair has only been used once. If I could be guaranteed to receive the original pair, I would quickly purchase it again. B00OPZJDO0	but on longer rides (20 miles+) I noticed that the padding was too firm and actually caused some pretty major pain	I never thought I'd end up writing a review for what are essentially padded underwear, but here we are. I recently (within the past 3-4 months) started cycling for exercise. Initially I had trouble getting used to the rather unforgiving seat on my new bike, so I replaced the seat with a more padded model. This worked for a while, but on longer rides (20 miles+) I noticed that the padding was too firm and actually caused some pretty major pain. As an experiment I bought these and one other (cheaper) pair to see if they'd make a difference. Boy did they ever make a difference, and because I had another pair to compare them with, I found that these are vastly superior. They stay up and wear pretty much like a normal pair of boxer briefs. They're so comfortable that I often forget that the padding is even there. Best of all, no more pain while riding. These things are great.One note is that although the sizing numbers are accurate, the letter sizes are way different than normal American men's underwear sizes. I wear normal Hanes boxer briefs in XL and had to buy these XXXL to achieve a similar fit. So be careful when you pick your size.	Ryan Chaank	Color: Blue|Size: XXX-Large	B00MTE6RJI	/gp/pdp/profile/A3ISLCDY6DJ1T9/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	46	5	2016/11/03

B00OPZJDO0	Great for the price, fits and works well.	I bought these as an alternative for shorter rides. So far, they work well, I've used them on a 50 mile ride with no issue (although the ride was not non stop.).FIRST IMPRESSION:They fit well, up on your waist. It was at first uncomfortable, but in a few rides they felt much more better. They need some time to "break in". The padding is blue, and it has enough in the right spots, and on my first ride, I didn't feel any pain in the padding area. The fabric is sleek and is a better product than other cycling shorts. You can tell the quality by the fact it isn't transparent.FUNCTION:The cycling underwear works well. Compared to other competitors, this is better as it has silicone lined leg bands and use a chamois pad instead of a cheap gel pad. Furthermore, it uses a much higher quality fabric. This is much better than the similar Xcellent cycling underwear. It also wicks well, which is why it is better than normal underwear for cycling. Also, please note that this is meant to be worn underneath shorts or pants.This is good for the price, for all cyclists. It mimics the padding and fabric of higher quality cycling shorts. B00OPZJDO0	Good initial quality but poor design is uncomfortable in actual use	I purchased these to to wear under street clothes for bike commuting. I do a lot of recreational cycling and typically wear bike shorts or a cycling bib for longer distance rides, but was looking for something a bit more inconspicuous for shorter distance commutes. I was pleasantly surprised by the initial quality, especially given the price. The fabric quality and padding is good. My complaint is that the legs do not have a strong elastic band at the bottom and immediately ride up my thighs while riding. This causes all of the leg fabric on the shorts to bunch up in the crotch region, making these very uncomfortable for biking. A good pair of bike shorts will have a wide elastic band at the bottom of the leg; generally with a rubberized backing, to keep them from riding up your legs. That is what this pair of shorts needs. You are better off buying a pair of normal spandex biking shorts to wear under other clothes. These are very uncomfortable in actual use. I do think the padding is very good and I may try to sew these into another pair of shorts. B00OPZJDO0	Good shorts for the price	Pros:  Fit as expected, provides paddingCons:  Padding is a little thin, slide down while ridingI bike 30-50 miles a week and my seat was definitely a pain point, so I decided to purchase these padded shorts. The fit was true to my normal size, so there was no issue there.I found that these shorts also slide down just a little while riding, so I had to adjust them every lap or so.  It's not a huge deal, but I have other bicycle shorts that have a little of rubber to stop them from sliding.Overall, I think these were a good pair of shorts for the price ... but I have found that it may be worth paying a bit more if you need extra cushion and comfort. B00OPZJDO0	Not for me.	The material of these padded bicycle shorts was very nice.  They felt comfortable against the skin and provided no irritation or uncomfortable rubbing.  That being said, the padding was insufficient.  The pictures make it appear that the padding is very substantial; however, in person it is not.  I've not seen other brands that have any more padding than these in any stores or online either.  While ridding on even short distance trips the padding provided very little if any additionally comfort because the padding became so compressed or it did not exactly match up with the placement of my sit bones and therefor was not in the correct position to provide support. I would get more, but the thigh grippers are just too tight.Pretty happy with these shorts. I am fairly new to cycling, and have been riding in street clothes until recently. I wear a 36" waist jean, and I got the XL. I think the LG would fit perfectly, but my thighs would hate me. The padding is nice, and for my hour/hour and a half rides, it's comparable to the Canaris. I dunno about longer, but I suspect it would do just fine for a few hours. B00OPZJDO0	Great value. Highly recommend.	Decided to get back into bike riding to change up my running routine especially in the summer heat of Florida. I found that the cooling breeze of riding 12 to 15 mph allowed me to exercise longer without the feeling of imminent heat stroke. Like most riders, I struggled with seat discomfort and the tingly numbness associated with a standard seat. I decided to purchase a Hobson Easy Seat 2 which greatly reduced sit bone pain and helped extend my riding time well past on hour. I debated whether or not padded biking undergarments would help with a split seat, but for such a low price, I decided to try a pair of these. Based on other reviews, I bought a size larger than what I normally wear, and they fit great. I am 6'3",250 lbs and wear an XL, so I bought these in size XXL. I have tree trunks for legs, so the additional space in the larger size was needed in the thighs. When you first put them on, the extra padding in the crotch area feels very weird and I would not recommend walking around in them. However, once you get on the bike and get situated in a good position, these shorts allow you to go a very long time without experiencing that uncomfortable sit bone pain. I would highly recommend these to anyone who likes to ride their bike but finds themselves cutting their time short because of numbness. I have washed these twice now and they seem to be holding up well. I plan on purchasing more of these in the future.	Jiraf27	Color: Black|Size: XX-Large	B00CWVPCLM	/gp/pdp/profile/A1P1QVQLUHP87V/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	5	2015/09/18

B00OPZJDO0	Excellent riding shorts.	I was in the market for some riding pants. I purchased 1  of these and 1 of the Pearl izumi(3x the cost) to compare, this was my result.First impression: I noticed the Pearls are slightly longer in the leg, and the seams and linings look as though they may have more substance to them than the Baleafs. Putting them on- lets face it, these things feel weird when you aren't on your bike- but the Baleaf's seems to have noticeably softer materials inside, and even after a couple of washes, the Pearls seemed itchy at times. From what I can tell the Baleaf's also have thicker padding, which is nice if you have Hank Hill posterior syndrome like me.Conclusion after a few rides(20-30mi): The Baleaf take it HANDS DOWN. They are my favorite, for fit and comfort, and being as they are a third of the cost to the izumi's it was no question for me to quickly pick up 2 more pair to have on hand.I purchased large for both, I am 5'11 170 pretty average frame, they both fit well and as expected. B00OPZJDO0	Saved my ass....	Where to start.  I'll preface to say I'm new to cycling.  I recently purchased a road bike and very motivated to start my cycling fitness routine.  My first reality check was the discomfort to my backside.  Even in cycling shorts, my ass gave out long before my legs did.  I found a gel seat cover in the garage from one of my wife's old bike and put it on the seat for some extra padding.  This only seemed to make things worse and I could barely walk after a 9 mile ride.  My butt felt like it had been beaten and bruised.  I started looking at $100+ seats to get away from this pain and stumbled across this cycling "underwear" and decided I'd give it a shot.  It was a good price so low risk right?  Most of the reviews read that they ran small.  I'm a 36 waist and, reading the reviews, that tracked to an XL.  I ordered two pairs of the XLs which I received today.  I tried them on right away, my derrier still sore from the weekend beating it took.  First impression, they fit loosely.  Much looser than the compression cycling shorts I had become accustomed to.  If you've ever held up a pair of "granny panties" that's what they looked and felt like other than the thick padding.  They fit loose and made me question my decision to go with the XL.  In hindsight, I should have just gone with an XL and an L and see where I landed.  Again, these are billed as "cycling underwear" so I need some shorts to go over them.  They were loose fitting and I was missing the compression fit of cycling shorts.  Since I was still sore, I said "what the hell" and put the cycling shorts on over the "cycling underwear" - double padding.  It didn't feel overly bulky so I decided to go with it.  I got rid of the gel seat and back to the stock seat that came with my Cannondale.  It was a good ride and I exceeded my max on distance at 13.3 miles.  Tired but not overly sore in the butt like I was on my last ride.  I can work with this and I'm no longer in a rush to spend every nickel I can muster on a high end bike seat that may or may not make a difference.  Give this a try and I hope you have as good a luck as I did with these padded "granny panties". B00OPZJDO0	Worked excellently for my 2-day 100 mile bike ride.	I came back to give this product 5 stars.  These shorts protected my sit-bones even though I sit in a forward-leaning, road bike-style position when I ride.  I just completed a 2-day, 8.5 hour long, 100 mile bike ride yesterday and had no saddle soreness. These shorts WORK.  It turns out that the trick for me was to pull the waistband of these shorts up as high as I could without hurting myself. Once I did that, I didn't need to readjust or anything along the ride.  My sitbones were fine the night I finished the 100 miles, and today they feel like I was never on a bike to begin with.My original review, below:I have a lean, athletic build, and I wear a 32-33 waist in jeans.  The large was too big, so I returned it for a medium which fit much better, but still made me feel like I was wearing a diaper. I attribute the diaper feeling to the bulky cushioning in the shorts.  I hear that's how a lot of padded shorts feel, so I didn't take off any stars for that.  Just thought you should be warned.The shorts have ample cushion for your butt, that's for sure. And If you ride sitting in a fairly vertical or even reclined position, then I have no doubt that these cushions will greatly improve your comfort on long rides because the padding is situated to protect the parts of your "sit bones" that will contact the bike saddle when riding in that vertical or reclined position.  But I ride in a road bike-like setup, with my seat high, and my torso leaning forward. The part of my body that makes contact with my bike saddle are the extreme anterior of my "sit bones."  These shorts do not have cushion in that area to pad against that part of my sit bones that are in contact most while leaning forward in that racing position.  This is because the cushions in these shorts are placed in the bottom of the shorts like a ladies menstrual pad (Not trying to be gross, but that's exactly how the pads are situated and shaped in the shorts) and the cushions get narrow between your legs - too narrow to protect my sitbones when I am biking in my racing position.Overall: they seem to be very acceptable for bike seat setups that keep the rider in a more vertical or reclined position, not for forward-leaning setups.	Christopher B.	Color: Black|Size: Medium	B00CWVP8PC	/gp/pdp/profile/A321BHX7I6NRHN/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	5	2015/04/13

B00OPZJDO0	Excellent shorts. Great for newbies.	I am new to the padded bike shorts scene, and I have limited experience, but hopefully this review helps someone. I bought a pair of padded underwear from REI for $40+ and I bought these for $15.Ride one, I wore the REI shorts, and they were tight -- VERY TIGHT. I guess that's the point though; riders want tight shorts to keep things in place and prevent rashes or whatever. I did not favor this feeling, and I still don't, but I'm hoping I'll get used to it.Ride two, I wore these Baleaf shorts. They were significantly more comfortable. I wear size 32-34 underwear, and because other reviews indicate these shorts run on the small side (thanks guys!), I bought Large (34-36), which fit perfect! I only rode for 35 miles, but they managed to keep me comfortable the entire time. My favorite thing about these shorts (in contrast to the REI Novaro brand) is the material. This soft material stretches with ease, like a stocking. I do not feel as if my circulation is being cut off.Overall, I highly recommend these shorts. I will likely buy another pair. B00OPZJDO0	Five Stars	So far they are great	John T. Holman	Color: Black|Size: Large	B00CWVP9YC	/gp/pdp/profile/A2SI9W4TQBI0SJ/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	N/A	5	2014/07/08
B00OPZJDO0	Pass, despite the price.	Summary: I wore these once and didn't even make it a mile before I headed back to swap them for a different pair.  I took a shot because they were so cheap, but it's money wasted.  The padding is ample, albeit stuff and not at all form fitting; that's not a negative for me but it might be for some.  The fit seems true to size but the material is very thin and thereby very weak.  They're shorter than normal and offer not protection against chaffing.  When it comes ot cycling shorts you generally get MUCH longer life and a better fit the more you pay  - to a point anyway.  These seem to prove that in the opposite direction.Fit: True to size.  As other buyers have stated, the inseem is short and the legs ride up easily; there's none of the grippy silicone or elastics to keep the legs in place.  They ride up so bad that it looked like I went riding in a pair of tighty-blackies.Construction: The material is the thinnest I've ever seen in any garment I've ever bought; thin enough to be semi-transparent when normally stretched. B00OPZJDO0	Awkward bulk and displacement	As others have noted, the picture of the shorts is that of them inside-out. The padding is significant. B00OPZJDO0	Padding good - leg portion, not so much	This is my first pair of biking shorts or liners, so I can't draw comparisons to other brands or styles, and readers can take my inexperience into account as appropriate. The problem I found was in the leg portion--instead of staying fixed on my legs, they bunch up in the crotch and sometimes became a source of mild discomfort/chafing.I don't think this is a function of sizing--I am a 32 waist and bought mediums, and my thighs are neither toothpicks nor tree trunks.  The legs fit snugly but without constriction when I put them on.  The problem is that the material is a pretty lightweight nylon that doesn't stay in place as I move.This doesn't happen to such a degree that I stopped wearing them--the padding still makes them a plus on the whole. B00Z9PEITK	Nice, not see-through!	General notes: Material is opaque (not see through), however this may be slightly diminished in some colors. Price is great.Specifics (pluses and potential concerns): These leggings are made of highly stretchy fabric and I would not suggest getting a larger than usual size unless a looser fit is desired (or you have a lot of 'junk in the trunk', a size up may help ensure these will be opaque). B00Z9PEITK	Great leggings for the gym and for daily use	After a few wears, I actually bought another pair because I was very happy with these. They are form-fitting as one qould expect from this type of legging, so they are pretty flattering. They're definitely opaque, and fairly thick but still quite comfortable. Since they're fairly thick, I don't feel especially cold outside as the temperature drops; I find the warmth fairly comparable to jeans that are on the thinner side.I have worn these to the gym and I also wear them for daily use. I don't feel weird using them as pants.I never use the little pocket, but I guess it's a nice feature for anyone who might need to put their ID or credit card somewhere. The logo is on the left near the top, so if you're wearing a fairly short shirt it is visible. I usually wear sweaters or tank tops and they cover the logo fine. They are also not seamless, rather the seams are definitely visible, but I don't think they're unsightly or anything, they're just there.Also, I bought a size small, and they fit wonderfully. I'm 5'2" and 120lbs for reference. They're slightly long but I usually wear boots over them anyway, and at the gym I just fold the bottom up, so that doesn't bother me at all. Honestly, I've given up finding reasonably-priced bottoms that are the right length. B00Z9PEITK	Are they see through? Well, kind of.	I like these leggings. They fit well in my usual size, are soft and stretchy and comfortable, and not too excessively long on my 5' frame. Here's the big question, though: are they see through? I have the black and navy (blue iris) colors, and the answer is: sort of. I did the bend-over test in a few different rooms in my house, and in some lights they looked completely opaque and in some lights they were, yes, a bit see-through in the butt area. I debated sending them back, but honestly, most leggings are kind of see-through if you bend over in certain lights, and I pretty much always have my butt covered when I wear leggings as pants anyway, so I kept them and even ordered a second pair in black. The softness and otherwise great fit won over the slight sheerness. I did the bottom 1/3 in cool water hoping to prevent it shortening too much since the dress is 38% cotton. B01J24C0TI	It is a very good device the Echo Show and it has some better ...	This was used to replace a Sony Dash that they bricked. It is a very good device the Echo Show and it has some better traits and some not as good traits as the device it replaced. I'm thinking that some of the things the other one did will be coming to the Show in the future. The show is very literal in what it hears and it takes getting used to which code words to do tasks. An example would be having it play some background music like a rain forest sound. You ask it to play rain forest sound and it tries to get albums by artist about rain forests instead of playing the skill sound. Speaking of Skills, that is what Amazon calls the things that Echo Show learns to feed you content. There are many of these skills and some might be a use as we move forward. I enabled a skill for that rain forest sound but it wouldn't play. The code word matters. Some are "Play" some are "Open" and then there are others. You would think a sound would play but in this case it is open. Other than that it is pretty accurate when you say something as long as it is clearly spoken. Overall it isn't perfect but it may get better. I like it for what it is even though there are some quirks in the interface.	Robert G. B01J24C0TI	Could be promising in newer generations.	I bought this to replace the echo classic in my bedroom and move that along with my echo dot to other locations in the home.First if you're expecting a lightweight easily portable thin profile device, this is likely to disappoint. Personally I initially supported the low centre of gravity design. I had no intentions of it being portable and while I love my echo dot, I was pleased not to have to find a another speaker solution in a space limited area like a bedroom.  However I found the speaker to be only about 50% the quality of the echo classic.My biggest problems and the ultimate reason I'm returning it though is not because it's clearly a beta product that was rushed to market. I think I knew that going in and wanted to be on the ground floor anyway.  That said I can't keep the darn thing from going offline and flashing the red bar of death.  This might be slightly inconvenient if you have to say...use it as an alarm to be up for work. B01J24C0TI	Thank You Amazon!  and my 95yr Mom Thanks you! (If she could).	I know that many media folks have stated that the "Drop-in" feature of the Echos is "creepy" and can see their point.  Here's a different perspective.  Mom is now almost 95 and she has short term memory dementia, she's in great spirits but I really can't teach her anything technical, like dialing a phone or even pressing a memory dial button.  She lives near my sister and is 2 hours away so visiting is always a bit of a project.I thought I'd try setting a Show next to her rocking chair.  I can now "Drop-in" on her every day and share some face time with her, visit with her grand daughter, see the dog whom she LOVES, and just make her smile.  The beauty is that there is no interaction needed on her end, the Caregivers and my Mom love this setup.  The fact that I can use my phone from anywhere and actually see and talk to Mom, and show her things  is hugely entertaining and comforting for Mom, and everyone in the family.So I say with extreme gratitude, Thank You Amazon for creating an amazingly personally helpful tool for the elderly.Personally I am enjoying all of the other great features of an Alexa with a screen, using her with my Arlo Cameras, etc. It truly is quite an amazing platform!  In my office I added a small Pioneer bookshelf stereo, I can be listening to Spotify, Pandora etc and say "Alexa, connect Bluetooth", the Pioneer stereo is Bluetooth enabled, it can be OFF and with that single voice command, the Show will wake up the Pioneer, and begin playing the sound over its speakers with no other intervention from me!  This is magical stuff!The only bug I have at the moment, "Alexa, turn off the screen", the screen turns off, then immediately turns back on. B01J24C0TI	Initial thoughts	Preordered 2 when they were announced. Overall it's a nice product. Much better speaker than the dot and nice and responsive touch screen. It's thicker than I thought it would be so fitting them on a small end table or night stand may create issues if you have other stuff like we do. For most people it's probably not worth the cost of around 3-4 echo dots. The dot does pretty much everything the show does (I had 6 dots) just no screen so while it's nice not really a need right now. The issue is unless friends and family also have the echo show you can't really use the video "drop in" feature that was a main featured selling point. Pains of being an early adopter I guess. I think with a few software tweaks it could and will be a lot more useful. Things like ringing your phone when you don't have the echo app open when someone calls from an echo device would be much more useful since I don't have echo app open usually. Also it would be great to be able to hang the device or having a removable camera so you can place it without having to move the whole unit around would allow you to use it as a baby monitor. Right now I don't know how you can as the camera is naturally positioned slightly upward due to the device being slightly tilted back when sitting on a flat surface. Anyways I'm sure it will get better but w/o that killer app/feature I would imagine that the dot which can do like 99% of the things that the show can for 1/4 the price is what most people will buy.Lastly Amazon if you're reading please don't forget about Alexa like Apple did with Siri (that's hard for me to admit being a huge Apple guy). Don't rely too much on 3rd party apps as she needs to continuously improve so she doesn't end up being useless. B01J24C0TI	I just don't understand how anyone can give this a bad review. This is such an incredible device	Not sure how to make this show as "verified purchase" when you get it from Prime Now but that's how I bought it.  I just don't understand how anyone can give this a bad review.  This is such an incredible device.  Like every Alexa device (and Google Home), you can speak and get it to play music, play radio stations, give you the news and weather.  But the screen adds a very useful bit of functionality.  For instance, the one thing Alexa always had that Google Home does not have is the ability to make and update a to-do list.  But with Echo show, you can ask her to show you your to-do list and up comes the list on screen. You can then say "delete number 4" or whatever.....and she zaps that item away.  Same stuff applies with making and keeping a shopping list.Throughout the day, Alexa alerts me to breaking news with headlines on the screen....including birthdays from my Facebook friends. Or announcements that I have a package coming in.The one complaint I've seen over and over, usually from people who haven't bought it, is that it looks clunky.  NO IT DOES NOT.  Place it on your desk or kitchen counter and it defaults to something that looks like a table-top clock....and it keeps the time and weather on the screen.  It actually looks very much like a futuristic time and weather device.....but hidden underneath is a world of power.  It's great and I'm glad I bought it. B01J24C0TI	The Echo Show is worth checking out	First of all I would like to mention I did not purchase this from Amazon. It was an impulse buy at Best Buy while going to buy an additional wemo plug. I would have to somewhat compare this to an old Sony Dash but with more capabilities. Back a few years Sony came out with a product called the dash. It was a great addition to my kitchen but then they dropped all support and essentially bricked it. I have been looking for a replacement for years but could find nothing that came close. Then along comes the Echo Show. A device that is shaped and had everything I loved about the short lived Sony dash but with the addition of having Alexa and some other nice features like not having to leave the kitchen when cooking to view my Arlo camera feeds. So now I think ok I am liking this although I do wish it was a bit more compact. The setup was a quick painless process unlike some other devices I've recently purchased. Speaker quality is better then the original Echo, and defiantly better then a dot or tap. I also find it a bit creepy that it knows when your in the room or not. It goes to a black screen with a clock when it doesnt detect you through the camera and when it does it returns to the "home screen". I also like how you can customize the background on the home screen. I find that it has trouble hearing me when my window a/c unit is on or a fan is on in the same room so that could use some improvement there. I would probably buy another one for the basement at some point. I think the positives overweigh the negatives with this unit. B01J24C0TI	NOT what I expected	I have embraced Alexa and have several dots placed throughout the house.  From almost every corner Alexa can hear me and she respond appropriately.  Almost every light in the house is connected to her and I love the functionality.  I pre-ordered the Echo Show about a month before it came out and I am disappointed.  Partly my fault for expecting more and partly an inferior product in my opinion.The screen works as advertised however the touch functionality does not seem to be as responsive as a phone or tablet.  This could just be me but it doesn't seem to take inputs very well.The speakers sound ok but don't hold a candle to a dedicated Bluetooth speaker you could pickup for $40 (generic) to $79 for a Bose Soundlink.The microphones do not seem to work very well.  I have the cheaper Dots and they work much better.  I have the Show in my kitchen and when I ask Alexa to start a timer (she is 5 ft away) 4 times out of 5 the Show does not pickup the voice command and my Dot in the other room 30 ft away does.I was expecting a fully functional Fire tablet with a built in speaker and 7 microphones with Alexa highlighted as the center Jewel.  The show is NOT what I expected.  It is literally the brains and power of a Dot with a screen that displays SOME information.  Yes you can see the words to songs but amazon charges a premium for this service---No thanks.  I really wish this was a fully functional android system (more specifically overlaid with Amazon's fire ecosystem) so I could check emails, view my full calendar, make adjustments to my calendar by voice, manage multiple apps and grocery lists, etc etc.The good:-Well built-Alexa is in there-Yes the Show is a screen, speaker, and far-field microphones all wrapped into oneThe Bad:-VERY limited functionality using the screen-Microphones do not work half as well as those on the $39-$49 Dot-Bulky for what it is-Not much benefit over other Alexa modelsTo be fair I have not reached out to Amazon yet to see if my unit isn't working properly in regards to the microphones NOT picking up my voice when I'm in the room near the device.I would recommend passing on this device at the current price of $229.  In my opinion the unit is worth $129-$149 when you consider you can get a more functional Fire tablet for $49-$79 depending on size/specs.I would recommend buying an echo Dot and Bose soundlink along with a fire tablet.  Mount the tablet to the wall and have the Dot sitting next to it.  This setup would cost slightly less than the show and you will have better sound, Better microphones, and a fully functional touchscreen for every task chore, video, music, recipe viewing, calendar, note, website to browse etc etc.  From what I understand the new tablet responds to voice anyways so maybe the dot is overkill just get the tablet and connect it to a speaker and you will have a much more functional unit for half the price. B01J24C0TI	What to do with that display?	I was an early adopter of the original Echo.  I have an Echo Dot too.  So when I saw the Echo Show, I was all ready to dive in. The speakers inside the unit are nice, and they will fill a room with sound.  The display is bright enough during the daylight hours, and it will adjust in brightness as the ambient light in the room changes (though it does NOT get dim enough at night to be a real nightstand clock -- I hope you're listening Amazon). B01J24C0TI	Device of the future after software and some hardware issues are solved.	7/17/2017: The Echo Show seems like sneak preview of the future as a small touchscreen with touch + voice command and decent speaker system will be the swiss army knife data collection point for home automation, security, personal scheduling, sleep tracking, baby monitoring, weather and news, etc.But, this device is not the future yet. Both the native software interface and third-party support are as clunky as the Agro Cragg Industrial Design.  3rd party support including the screen will likely grow but it's currently limited and an on-board "skills store" for finding new skills is sorely needed. The touchscreen doesn't support or even display the same selections as voice navigation so you're left guessing what to tell Alexa in order to navigate and it's pretty frustrating at times when you can't find the right YouTube video, etc.The speaker playback is good for a device this size, a hair muddled in voice reproduction. Also background noise (hiss) is audible at lower levels (25% or below) during content playback. That is not a problem on the original Echo. It would be nice to see a live on-screen translation of speech-to-text to determine whether it didn't understand what I said because it translated speech-to-text incorrectly or whether it translated it correctly and couldn't interpret a command from what was said.However, if used on a nightstand next to a bed (which I would expect is probably either the first or second most common usage of this device), there are additional troubles which make this unusable. First is that the backlight on the screen is too bright even if showing a clock on black background (do-not-disturb mode). Second is the power supply emits a tone which (7kHz, 45 dB at 1 meter as installed) which makes it almost impossible to sleep in a quiet environment.I expect I'll like this better with continued software updates; however, the screen and power supply issues mentioned above mean that I will likely be returning one for now. B01J24C0TI	GREAT PRODUCT, SURPRISINGLY USEFUL!	What, an Amazon Alexa that has a screen? I of course thought gimmick! However, over a period of two weeks I have found the Show to be incredibly useful.The unit guides you though setup and makes it easy to personalize for your needs. For those of you not familiar with how Alexa works, you must load the app on your phone, (free download,) and select SKILLS. Skills are functions that alexa can perform. You load these skills and set them up the way it best suits your own uses.For instance, I set up a skill that allows me to find where in my home I put my iPhone. I say:"Alexa, find my phone." Alexa responds with "Do you want me to call your phone?" I respond and my phone rings, hiding from me under a pillow on the couch!There is an important fact that you should be aware of. If you set up your Show and expect it to work perfectly immediately, that is not the case. You do have to wait a few minutes for the server to capture and set up your data. I waiting about 10 minutes and everything was fine. Unfortunately I learned this the hard way! Right after setup I immediately gave commands like "Alexa, turn on my hallway air cleaner" or "Alexa turn on master bedroom light."Drove me crazy as it would just not work, Finally I talked to a support person at Amazon and he was the one to inform me that you had to give their servers time to process your data. After about 30 minutes, it worked perfectly.Luckily Amazon was smart enough to set up a customer service area just for Alexa help and questions. Just call customer service and ask them to connect you to Alexa Support. Once there, you can ask the support rep to send an email listing all the ways you can contact them.As for the screen, it's nice and bright, clear and quite legible in a dark or bright room. You can ask Alexa for a Flash Bruefing and will get be you a short newscast right on the screen from a source you previously selected; mine was CNN.The sound is decent and is not distorted even at slightly high levels. The audio from their speakers is definitely decent unless you are a real audiophile.Alexa Show is not inexpensive, but if you use it all the time like I do, it is worth the investment!	Dennis M	Color: White|Configuration: Echo Show	B010CEHQTG	/gp/pdp/profile/A2EUKK3NEJLLLM/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	1	5	2017/07/16

There is not separate volumes for when Alexis speaks to you and the music playback so expect to be adjusting the volume often so you can hear what Alexa is saying if you're like me you listen to music at a low volume especially at night time when sleeping when I wake up in the morning I like to ask her the briefing or the weather but the volume down low from the music so I have to stop her turn the volume up and then start over then when I go to play music the music is blasting loud. This should be a simple fix considering there are separate volumes for the alarm. Another problem no IR lights which means no night vision so if you doing a video or just checking in on a room you have to turn the lights on. B01J24C0TI	Dim Screen	I pre-ordered my Echo Show for automatic shipment to me when available. Setup was very easy, but when I played music I heard horribly distorted sound which I believed could not be normal. I decided to request a replacement. Amazon immediately shipped another unit to me which I received 2 days later and requested return of the defective unit within 30 days for full credit and no shipping charges. After setup, the Alexa app on my iPhone showed the replacement listed as Echo Show 2. The Echo Show was listed as Offline and the Wake Word was grayed out. I was able to change the Echo Show 2 Wake Word to "Echo". Ideally there would be voice commands to increase/decrease brightness or at least a fixed level brighter screen. OK.  That worked.  (It took 1.5 hours to figure that one out)4)  This begs the question "Do I need a separate account for each Show I purchase?  What if I want a 3rd in my kitchen?5)  So, I call tech support ... again.  They inform me that I do not need another account for a 3rd Show but I do need to 'turn on' Drop-In.  If I do not have Drop-In turned on it will not work?  Huh?  Why is that?  They can not say.6)  The summary of this situation is that as 'kewl' as the produce idea is, Amazon Show is not ready for real customer use.  (It probably works well if you want to purchase just 1; but given their enticing offer of $100 off if you buy 2, I must say "If that is your need, look elsewhere.")  They should have a)  trained their support staff on the product and it's features and b) beta tested multiple product use.  But, apparently Amazon uses it's customers as beta testers.I am returning my devices. B01J24C0TI	The camera integration with various Smart Home providers also works decently	The Echo Show is definitely an interesting product. If you haven't interacted with one in person, it's basically an Android driven touchscreen built into an Echo device. Unlike a typical Android tablet, however, there are no icons and very little interaction is done with the touchscreen.By default, the screen simply shows the time and current weather in the top left, with a rotating view of Alexa tips, calendar events and news items on the bottom portion of the screen and a randomly chosen background picture.When you talk to Alexa, a blue gradient bar appears on the bottom edge of the screen (reminiscent of the blue light on the original Echo) and the text of her response shows up on the screen. If there are multiple choices, they are listed on the screen and you can reference them by number as well as touch them.The camera integration with various Smart Home providers also works decently, albeit a bit slow to connect sometimes. But overall, the touchscreen on the Echo Show puts an interesting spin on the concept of the Echo devices.	Michael	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A2TGFFF3MOY48H/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	N/A	4	2017/07/12

B01J24C0TI	Really like it so far	First off people need to understand this is not a voice activated tablet. This is the echo with a screen. I so far like it a lot. When turned up it's very loud and I can hear music from it well into the next room and even upstairs. Is it as good as some of the top Bluetooth speakers out there no but its a step up from the echo and I am happy with it. The sound when using it for calls is good very clear.The Screen- When I first got my echo my first thought was why does this not have a screen? So when I saw the Show I was very excited. I love being able to look at it to see what song is playing or sing along to a song I don't know the words tpp(though its prime music only not your own library which kind of stinks).Video Calling- This feature was one that I was also excited about. I bought one for myself and one for my parents. We have been using Skype for years but it seems to be getting buggier and more annoying. The show does it well. Good video and sound easy to use perfect for what we use it for. It does stink a little that the camera can not be rotated at all the camera is at a high angle and a little annoying but it's not a huge deal to me.Everything Else- I am disappointed in what skills work with the show at the moment I am sure more will be coming but it would have been nice to have a few ready to go. B01J24C0TI	Amazon's in the lead	The Echo show is so much fun! The screen is clear and has good color. I've been updating my house with smart devices, and the 'show' controls them along with my other echoes and dots. Lights, thermostat, cameras. I really like that I can just ask Alexa to show me one of the camera views, and there it is on the screen. No running to get my phone or iPad to use the device app. The drop in feature is helpful and fun too. I bought my parents a 'show', and they love that feature! lol. It allows you to activate one of your contact's 'show' screen (drop in) and video chat. (it will warn the person you are contacting, that you are 'dropping in'). The only down part for me is that I wish Amazon would have used more premium speakers. Not a deal breaker. I just use my Bose Bluetooth speaker. I'm still discovering more about it, but it has already been so useful. This is definitely the wave of the future, and Amazon is light years ahead. B01J24C0TI	Good concept, but sadly, I had to send it back.  This is why...	It makes a great toy for a few days but as novelty wears off it becomes more of a toy than can actually be used for utility (what we were hoping to use it for when we bought it).Pros:1.  The voice assistant is about 2 years ahead of Siri, which is why we gave it 3-stars "it's okay" and not 2-stars "I don't like it".2.  We can naturally speak and it understands us over 50% of the time.3.  Pretty solid speakers and display.Cons ("major" irritations that outweigh the cool-factor benefits):1.  I shouldn't have to buy a separate $150+ device ("Amazon Echo Look") in order to take a picture or short video of myself.  This device has all the hardware it needs to do just that.  I understand Amazon doesn't want to cannibalize its own devices, but seriously?  Common, man.2.  There seems to be no volume equalizer.  When I'm listening to my flash briefing, I have to constantly interrupt the device to turn volume anywhere between 4 and 7.  Almost every briefing is like this.  This should be a simple fix in a future update, but for now it's irritating to change the volume for each briefing.3.  When I add apps (or "skills"), it will automatically add what it deems "news" into my flash briefing.  I want to be able to independently activate just one of them without having to listen to the whole briefing and constantly interrupting it to say "Alexa - Next!" (wait 2 seconds), "Alexa - Next!" (wait 2 seconds), "Alexa - Next!" (wait 2 seconds), "Alexa - Next!" (wait 2 seconds), "Alexa - Next!" (wait 2 seconds).  Oh, finally the briefing I want.  Yes, I am aware I can change the order of the briefing, but this should also be an easy fix.Minor irritations:1.  No customizable home screen.  Well, extremely limited.  Give me widgets.2.  Although it can hook up to bluetooth, it doesn't support Apple Music.3.  No 24-hour clock option.  My wife and I run on 24-hour clock (like the rest of the world).  When I ask to set an alarm for 3 o'clock, I expect it to understand it means afternoon and not ask me "Is that 3 o'clock in the morning, or afternoon?" B01J24C0TI	It's getting there...	Getting there, but needs a better UI to be a killer device.The good:The hardware is awesome. The speakers in it sound great, and the touch screen produces sharp images and the response time feels fast and accurate. The video calling function also produces nice and clear video calls.The not-so-good:The user interface is a little wonky.  If I'm listening to something on the device and get a phone call or some other sort of interruption, the device doesn't properly resume what I was listening to. If my news flash briefing is interrupted, then it won't resume playing, and when I ask it to resume my flash briefing it starts over from the beginning. Also, navigating through the device doesn't appear to be fully baked yet. Sure, I can ask the device to pull up certain videos on YouTube, but it would be much easier if there were a YouTube app that I could scroll through so I could choose from videos of which I don't know the precise name of. There's a beautiful touchscreen on the thing and Amazon has provided few ways of actually using it. Ideally there would be apps available on a home screen, and not hidden somewhere behind a series of voice commands. It would be so nice if the thing had a ton of apps so I could easily pick something from Netflix or Hulu, or a recipe app.The on screen suggestions are also a little annoying. I don't need a collection of banners that read "Ask Alexa to play John Mayer songs", or "Ask Alexa to tell me more about Rob Kardashian's Twitter Meltdown". I would like to have the option of a photo slideshow when the thing is not in use. Right now it just cycles through these annoying banners.I have faith in Amazon though. B01J24C0TI	The sound quality is very good. It gives a nice rich sound for watching ...	The setup process for the Echo Show was a little quirky -- more so than other Echo devices I've setup (I have an Echo, 6 Dots, and 2 Shows).  I had to restart it and connect to the network several times, but once setup, I've been impressed.  I have it in my home office and play movies from Amazon Prime Videos while working.  The sound quality is very good.  It gives a nice rich sound for watching movies.  Pausing a video will cause it to stop in just a few seconds.  It would be nice to persist on the pause screen longer (until dismissed).I have played around with the calling capabilities a bit, but it is not a primary driver feature for me.I ordered a couple of items on Amazon PrimeDay from the Echo Show and the process was super simple.  It gave me more confidence seeing the product I'm ordering rather than voice ordering from my Echo / Echo Dot (as I've done in the past).Now that Echo has a display, I would love to see some apps available for home automation, like visual control for my Hue lights or an app for my Ecobee thermostat.  When Echo/Sonos integration is finally released, I'd definitely like a Show Sonos Music control app.Finally, I'd like more control over the screensaver, like being able to turn off the "Try.." suggestions altogether, instead of just limiting the scope. B01J24C0TI	The screen adds little to Home Automation products except for Arlo.  Needs ability to view web pages.  Disappointing.	After spending a week with the Show, I am wanting so much more.  I primarily purchased it for use with home automation products like SmartThings, Ring Video Doorbell, Arlo cameras, and Hue bulbs.  The video screen adds little to most of these products, except for Arlo.SmartThings:You can control SmartThings devices just like with a traditional Echo, but you cannot view statuses of window/door sensors, or control thermostats, etc on the screen.  I would love to see this added in the future and was expecting this at launch.Ring Video Doorbell:Probably the biggest disappointment.  I was expecting to be able to view and talk to people when they ring my doorbell.  Nope.  It won't show the video (apparently it isn't supported for the non-Pro version yet), and you cannot speak with the visitor on ANY Ring device.  Huge bummer, it was a big reason I purchased the Shows.Arlo cameras:It is very convenient to be able to view my Arlo cameras on the Show.  It works pretty well.  Images come up fairly quickly on my network when I ask to view a specific camera.  This was what most apps should have been like at launch.Hue bulbs:Again, no use of the screen when controlling Hue bulbs.  Why not show a color wheel, etc for selecting colors?Also, there is currently no way to turn off the constant barrage of tips and tricks like "Try this" and "Try that" on the screen.  It doesn't work with Google Music.  It doesn't answer questions very well unless you install an unsupported, hacky way of Googling.  For example, I asked Alexa "does Radon gas have an odor?" and it started reading me a news story about fuel in Germany.  Tried again, same thing.  I asked my Google Home as well as the unsupported Ask Google skill that takes awhile to install, and it immediately answered my question thoroughly.A huge feature would be the ability to view web pages on the Show.  That would allow me to control SmartThings and the Ring like I want to.  There is a hidden web browser on the Show, but it doesn't have an address bar so you can't specify where to go.Overall, it could be so much better. B01J24C0TI	Great, but can still get better with a few tweaks.	The Echo Show takes what you'd expect from the original Echo and expands upon it by adding a screen and a camera.  The screen is bright and sharp, and while not many skills take advantage of it (which is understandable considering Alexa is a voice-based service), the ones that do, provide some useful information such as news headlines, song lyrics, and weather forecasts and details such as humidity.  The home screen can display a slideshow based on photos stored on Prime Photos.The sound quality is acceptable, but seems to have more of an emphasis on the mids and lacks some clarity in the highs that while the Echo isn't particularly good at either, still does better than the Show.  The Show does get plenty loud enough for my uses without distracting amounts of distortion though.The Show's wifi performance seems a bit spotty, with the flash briefing seemingly having several second delays between each headline or the start of a podcast compared to the Echo, and even occasionally drops the wifi connection all together even though other devices remain connected without issue.The built in camera can take still photos by asking Alexa to take a picture, where Alexa will then ask for your camera options before snapping the shot.  I was pleasantly surprised at the photo quality, though the resolution isn't particularly high.The show's microphone array seems to have better hearing in general than the Echo, though occasionally it picks up what it thinks is the wake word even though nothing remotely like it was spoken.The screen dims when nobody is nearby and will come back on when someone is spotted on the camera.  The camera, like the microphone is always watching, but not broadcasting unless you're in a call for this to work, and like the microphones, can be turned on or off with a button.Annoyingly though, for now, there is no way to disable the tips that flash upon the screen, interspersed among news headlines and weather updates.  There also does not appear to be a way to set the clock to use 24 hour time, nor specify AM/PM on the display.  You cannot specify the slideshow cycle time, nor select multiple albums to choose slideshow pictures.  The ability to pick news sources or RSS feeds to display on the home screen would be nice. B01J24C0TI	Highly recommended	I read some of the other reviews and I guess it all comes down to what you are looking for. I have an Amazon Echo in the bedroom and the Show in the kitchen. I find it is everything it is advertised to be, and more. The setup is so easy I have watched 2 tech-noobs successfully do it in minutes. (These people constantly ask me things like "how do I find settings on my phone?").The customer service is just amazing. You call the help number given in the app and in a couple of minutes, you have a live person on the phone who goes the extra mile to get the right answer. I called a few times to get answers on some how-to things, like "can Alexa handle double-authentication on wifi - answer is yes). The rep double-checked with one of their wifi experts before giving me the answer. I also had a problem with the message notification bubble not appearing on my screen. Turns out I had to remove the middle initial from my registration name. I was surprised she figured that out so quickly.The screen is sharp and clear and I can easily read everything without my reading glasses. The prime music/video and youtube integrations are excellent and be sure to take a look at using the tunein application which offers some interesting podcasts and news. I like how, when I set a timer, it keeps going off until I dismiss it. I do wish you could personalize how many times Alexa gives you a reminder in case you are out of the room. Right now she tells you twice but the reminder is also displayed on the screen for a while.I am finding new cool things that Alexa can do everyday and I have no doubt that future updates will add more. If you are looking for a device that is compatible with Chromecast, this isn't for you. But if you are looking for a personal assistant that can make your life easier and add a bit humor (through easter eggs), I highly recommend it. B01J24C0TI	Great product for keeping in touch with elderly parents!	This is a brilliant product and even better than I had hoped.  I bought two so that I could check in frequently with my 90-year-old mother in another state.  Setup was surprisingly easy - just plugged it in and connected the Wi-Fi.  It has several advantages for this kind of application over a tablet.  First it's entirely voice controlled, so that once my mom learned to say "Alexa" before each command, she was able to access all kinds of information and make calls to family with just her voice.  No tablet to find, no buttons to push - just talking.  I'm able to easily make video calls to my mom with my iphone from anywhere.  It was also easy to connect a Google calendar to her Echo Show so that she could keep track of upcoming events.  She lives in a senior community and has short-term memory issues, so this help with keeping track of upcoming events is very useful.  We used the shopping list function and it worked beautifully - letting her add things to her list when she thought of them and then checking them off on her android phone at the store.  The speaker is great too.  She can ask for Glen Miller music and get a nice selection of favorite songs or she can ask for a preview of a movie she's heard about from TV, as well as getting movie times and locations.  In addition to using our own Echo Show for these things, my wife and I have both our calendars synced to it, so we know what events are coming up.  I can't say enough good things about it and I'm grateful to Amazon for bringing it to market and using the knowledge they've gained from the Echo to good effect. There are a lot of phrases you need to precede or follow up with to make it recognize certain words even though what you say is not incorrect. i'm seriously impressed with the staff and that they care to improve this to that extent. Some people it seems have issues with some things I don't and vise versa.  I love troubleshooting, but not at the cost of my money so for now i'm not changing my review.. but I give the staff 5 stars [End of edit]This is going to sound like i'm defending this product but i'll be honest with you all, i'm very dis-satisfied with it for many reasons.  However, I want to help.  I doubt anyone from the company that has anything to do with the development will ever pay attention to this but in the chance that they do, it's worth the effort.I'll Be as concise as possible with this review because there is so much to talk about.First of all,  What the Echo Show is NOT...1. it is NOT meant to be a tablet.2. It's NOT supposed to be something that is portable like a tablet or a phone.First The good...1. It's really high quality in hardware2. It looks professional3. it's heavy enough and non slide so that you are not likely to knock it down.4. The video quality is really nice for it's size screen and my eyes don't hurt watching it.5. I have never once had an issue with voice recognition.  NOT ONCE.  Most of the time I do have issues with things like that due to my southern accent but I have never had to repeat something to Alexa due to her not understanding it.  I have had to due to using the wrong words but that is not Alexa's fault.6. They really did an amazing job for an AI so early on for a product like this when it comes to interactions like saying good morning to her.  Could they have made it into something you would see in a movie? sure in time, but this is not a hollywood-ized product.7.  I really like the concept of adding skills to customize her like you like even though there are not many very good ones ... YET.8. The face to face talking is nice.. like bringing skype to the echo devices.9. The mic sensitivity is amazing.  alexa can hear me 2 large open rooms away.Now the Maddening BAD that I have high hopes that they will improve on.1. All the investing I have done in Amazon's services and The Echo Show doesn't use them!!!!  The Cloud service, amazon prime video, and the one it does use, amazon music,  it's so limited you might as well not even have it.  it doesn't compete with any of the other services out there.  They tried .. sort of ... it's a start?  if you want to pull up a single song or the front page of youTube you are okay then.  But that isn't enough for me.  I have paid for my services and yet I can't use them in an amazon device that would be rather simple to use through a device like that!  I paid more than a price of a tablet that can do 100x more than this can with amazon services.2. Amazon, don't tell people you can send a text or call people on your phone contacts and not tell the whole truth.  What they don't tell you is that supposedly your contacts have to be on your phone locally for alexa to see it..  However, THAT isn't even true... they not only have to be contacts on your phone but also have the echo app. Your advertising is misleading!  if you want people to put your app on their phones that don't have any echo product , you need to find a way other than buying your product to get people to WANT to. Find a better way to present it for crying out loud.  The app is very clunky at best and definitely not intuitive.  And if you don't have an echo product most of it isn't going to make much sense to them to even have !3. I realize you as the company want people to buy from you as much as possible... but you aren't going to get people to love alexa and the echo if you ram everything you sell down people's throats.  take off the dang ads on the display, the constant movement, give people a chance to make it like they want, ... it's extremely distracting and totally NOT usable in a bedroom.  too bright and constantly flashing around and lighting up the room.4. This product has so much potential but it's like you crammed a clunky phone app in this nice piece of hardware that looks so amazing and totally cheapened the experience and made us alpha testers.... that HAD to pay to get the experience.  I would test this product till my voice is raw and with pride if I didn't have to pay for this early version as if it was a several year old tested product.  I don't mind paying for good product.  But I bought two of these and I felt like i could have bought two tablets and got a LOT more functionality out of it.5. Seriously in need to filter some of the skills on the app as well... some of them are just horrible and hold alexa up so bad with no ability to exit that you have to turn it off just to get out of it.6. No touch menu ability... well ... you touch the thing to confirm to turn it off.  >,<  There is one or two other places I found you could in a limited way. You need some way to get the heck out of the apps without turning it off one some of those skills.... or be able to browse the music or videos you should be able to access or currently can!There are so many other good and bad points to this product but I just don't ahve teh time and honestly i'm giving Amazon my time for free to do this.  I really am an amazon fan.  even tried to apply for a job once that required a master's degree at least..so i'm extremely disappointed in the product that is part of a product line that is part of their branding.now.  please amazon.. don't throw that away.  I won't send the product back because hardware wise there is nothing wrong with it, but i wish I hadn't spent my money on the two Echo Shows all the same.  There are very few businesses I believe in anymore...and I don't want to stop believing in this one.  we all mess up,  I just ask you make this right with a product I would be proud to offer if it were mine.. isn't that what you are supposed to be about?  I know you are very large now compared to 1994 starting in that garage, but don't have to lose the integrity of that garage business.  Love amazon, love the lines, and love how you make my life much easier and higher quality with the services.Create an awesome day for yourselves.~ish	ishKiia	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A2HTDXRUJP6JGY/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	13	2	2017/07/08

B01J24C0TI	Not ready for prime time!	I have very much been looking forward to getting my Show, & bought two of them. However, I am FAR from being satisfied with its performance. I'm a professional engineer, with more than 50 years technology experience, & I have 18 Amazon devices listed under www.amazon.com/mycd, so I'm not exactly an amateur on their products. I also own a computer consulting company that has dealt with integrating audio, video, & computer networks for more than 30 years, & our home is very "smart."However, in the two days I have been running my Show, it has failed to respond to voice commands 19 times, so far. That includes simple ones, like "Alexa, Stop" & "Alexa, Continue." The unit is sitting 18 inches from me, so it's not like it's unable to pick up my voice, & when I switch back to my Alexa Echo, that unit works perfectly, as usual. Not only does the Show fail to respond, it also responds incorrectly, although fewer times. I find myself getting angry at an inanimate - but supposedly intelligent - object, which is not a good thing at all!I found that I cannot run both my Echo & Echo Show at the same time, at least not while they're sitting a few feet from each other, so I keep two Firefox tabs open so I can switch back & forth...usually because the Show has stopped responding.The video screen is a very nice feature, but there's no obvious way to return to a Home screen, except by just waiting. The touch-screen just...isn't touchable. In fact, the touch feature works so UNreliably, that I quit using it within an hour of setting up the Show, & I consider it useless. The pull-down menu gets you to commands, but there isn't any way to back up one level, & I found myself having to use the pull-down multiple times to get anything done, a very-inefficient way to accomplish anything.I contacted Amazon Technical Support to ask some questions, & it was painfully obvious that their technicians have no idea how to provide service advice for the Show; one tech disappeared for almost 20 minutes before I got fed up, & closed the Chat session. I have sent several e-mails asking how to identify non-Amazon smartphones so that I can use the Alexa app to communicate, but have received nothing that makes any sense, almost as if they're answering a totally different question.One good thing is that setting up the Show was utterly painless, & has been the most-useful feature I've found so far. It took me less than 10 minutes, including the multiple software updates & reboots the device went through. The Show's speakers are marginally better than the Echo's, but not as "room-filling" as their advertising led me to believe.In short, perhaps the software updates will make the Show into a device that I can rely upon, but it's not at all ready for prime time right now! So, instead of sending the second Show as a gift to my sister (who has no experience with Amazon's voice-operated devices), I will hold onto it for now, just in case I have to return both units. I have 28 more days to make that decision, &, regretfully, I think it's a toss-up. I'll come back & revisit these comments over the next few weeks, just in case I'm pleasantly surprised.UPDATES: I just took away a star! I've had the Show for not quite a week, & I am pretty sure that I'm going to return both of them to Amazon. I've been keeping a list of problems & observations, as follows:Need to be able change music lyrics font sizeLoss of music station multiple times (Echo plays okay)Multiple instances of "Something has gone wrong"Multiple instances of "What do you want to play?" after "Alexa, Stop"After turning on Smart Home, Alexa says it's not on, so no camera availableAt 10:03 PM on 7/11/17, despite me almost screaming at the Show five or six times, it would NOT stop, & I had to use the application on my computer to make the extremely loud commercial pause! This is totally unacceptable! Then, when I tried to restart the music, the Show told me that the station was unavailable, when I could get it to play on the Echo, right beside it, & the Windows app could no longer connect to the Show.The Show responds only randomly to the app on the computer, sometimes ignoring it completely, other times responding after seconds, or even minutesWhy have a touch-screen, when 99% of the gestures don't work?The Show should be able to show the name of the song that's playingThe Show continues to stop arbitrarily for no reason at all, & will not restart on the same music station; this isn't happening with the EchoNOTE: I did get a phone call from an Amazon tech support person after I wrote my first negative review, which means that they are very interested in user feedback, & he agreed with all of the problems I mentioned, telling me that they are "working to resolve them." That is, frankly, the ONLY reason that I haven't packaged these up & sent them back! My computer company has been doing beta-testing for more than 30 years, & I feel it only fair to give Amazon the full 30 days to get these problems resolved, but I'm sure not seeing any sign of things getting better!Having music & other features stopping arbitrarily, having blaring commercials that CANNOT be shut down, & having a device that ignores its own app are all problems that MUST be fixed!! It's not bad enough that computers can drive me crazy - I don't have to put up with a voice-activated device that refuses to listen, too!	Kenneth M. B01J24C0TI	Echo Show is GREAT for video calling.	I pre-ordered two of these a couple of months ago, and have had them on deck for about a week now, one in my son's home in PHX and one in my home in Utah.I bought them primarily for the video calling and messaging functions. After a couple of calls between the two units, I can say that I'm satisfied that my reason for buying has been justified. Call quality was excellent; no breakup (pixelation) such as Skype calls are afflicted with, decent video resolution, no voice/video sync issues, no lag. Works better than I expected for this function. A minor niggle under CONS. A secondary reason I wanted the SHOW is for viewing my five Arlo cams on demand. This also works well enough, though the skill could use a little tuning. I'm sure that will happen. The only issue with it is that there is some delay while "Connecting to Netgear", which can't be blamed on the Echo. Same thing happens when checking cams from my phone, or even from my DT which is in the same room as the Arlo hub (with both hardwired via Ethernet.) Also a Netgear issue is that it sometimes takes more than one try to connect to a camera. Netgear should probably try to fix this issue, it's longstanding. But I digress. The skill COULD display multiple cameras at once, as you see on the phone app and the web app. But it doesn't. Maybe someday. Other pros and cons, subject to revision after the device SW and skills mature:PROS:YouTubeLyrics onscreen when playing from Prime MusicPhoto slideshow from your Prime Photos as a homescreen background, if you wantSpeakers are very decent for voice and quite decent for music (also a CON; see below.)Can display calendar appointments on demand (Google Calendar used.)Drop-In feature works well for room-to-room intercom.Seems to reconnect & become usable more quickly than tall Echos and Dots when unplugged & moved.Solidly built, pleasing aesthetic (I bought black.)Bright screen, touch sensitivity a little low for me...an adjustment in settings would be nice.CONS:Speakers (also a Pro; see above.) The speakers are very directional, covering the 180 degree arc in front of the SHOW well, but sound quality drops dramatically as soon as the listener moves to the side or rear of the unit. This primarily affects music quality. If it's up against a wall or in a corner, should be fine, but we keep ours on the kitchen counter which is open to great room, and behind the device music is thin, flat, watery. To be expected, I guess, with speakers oriented toward a screen viewer. We've been spoiled by the sound from the tall Echos. One located in the center of the great room provides excellent coverage throughout that area and the kitchen as well, with no directional blind spots. Definitely our choice for music. Stick with the tall Echo for great streamed or BT music. We rarely use our Bose BT or the Big Jambox we've had for years anymore...Echo tall is that good. As good as Bose/Big Jambox? No, not quite, but very close. Besides, if you want to use your favorite BT music speaker paired with the SHOW, you certainly can.Home screen: Inability to have granular control over what's displayed on HOME screen. I HATE that SHOW rotates through a bunch of unwanted and unneeded suggestions on what to ask Alexa, overprinted onto my chosen BG images (photo slideshow.) LET US TURN THAT OFF! I called Amazon CS, and the guy was great, spent about 30 minutes with me, but neither of us could turn it off. Minor niggle...the screen darkened during a lengthy video call as part of SHOW's screensaver logic, and I couldn't get it to brighten again without rebooting after the call. Amazon should definitely write into the OS so that the screen NEVER darkens when a video call is in process. How hard can that be? Also, I read that the inactivity screen darkening is supposed to see new activity around the device and brighten again on approach; it's flaky, unreliable at present. Needs a tune-up.ALL IN ALL, I'm happy with the purchase, but here's a REALLY, REALLY BIG THING for Amazon, and one that would send the sales of ALL Echo devices through the roof, and probably kill the Google Home to boot: Being able to listen to a music stream on all or selected multiple devices throughout the house. Goggle Home can do this. Right now we have two tall Echos, three Dots, and one Show. If Amazon would enable synced music streaming, I would have a device in every room, and as a side benefit to Amazon, I might subscribe to Prime Unlimited Music instead of just using the free Prime Music.I'm sure I'll have updates after a few more weeks of use. BTW, I've had two SW updates not including the initial one on first boot, so I know they're working on stuff. As someone who owns many of these smart assistants (3 full sized Echos, 3 dots, 1 Goggle Home and now 2 Echo Shows) and has extensive amount of use with them, I think I can speak to most of what you want to hear. :)This review will also address future models from Microsoft and Apple as well.I gave the Echo Show four stars even when it is clearly the best product released or announced right now. I did this because it is clear that this is a first generation device and needs to design tweaking to make it five stars. That being said, it is the best smart assistant out right now and will be for the rest of the year (if not longer).Right now if I was purchasing more units they would be Echo Shows. (This is out of the three Amazon products, the Google product and its possible future product with Wifi mesh built in and the Microsoft future product and the future Apple speaker.)I would not pay more than one fifty for anything without a screen unless you are going to be using it for music almost exclusively (and even then there are likely better options in pure wireless speakers.)Amazon Echo Show:+ Improved mic listening. Not sure if this was software but it clearly is able to hear me better during music playback at higher volumes. I have often wondered why Amazon doesn't just automatically cancel out the audio it is playing to what it is hearing as that simple fix would help a lot. I am not sure they have fully done that but they did something that makes the mic more responsive. (Since this could be software related, you might see this fix applied to the other Amazon devices in the future.)+ First device with a screen. While they are still developing apps to use it, already it adds a bunch of functionality.+ Video calls! This allows you to use them as video intercoms in your house too which is really handy.+ Able to take still photos+ Able to display your photos+ Able to show things (like the weather, items from Amazon and lyrics for songs)BUT WAIT, there's more! Yes, Amazon made the screen a TOUCH SCREEN which means it is super useful for those times when selecting something is faster than trying to explain via voice what you want to do. This means it can replace a tablet for some light tasks. One of the single favorite things for me--wifi setup. It was SO much faster just to be able to type my wifi password directly instead of having to use a cell phone and the Alexia app and hoping it will work.+ Directly scroll through Amazon listings with photos, pricing and details and purchase items without having to have Echo "guess" what you mean.+ Having both a screen and touch sensitiveness means so many future apps/skills will be made possible.Plus compared to other brands products, nothing is as easy to use or more full featured than the Echo family. We recently purchased the Google Home to keep in the living room to compare it to the Amazon Show we have in there and commonly my wife and I ask the same question of both devices. I was (and continue to be) shocked at how much Google Home's device can't answer or how wordy it can be when actually doing something. For example, this means playing music takes longer to start.More surprising to me is the lack of progress Google seems to be making on the Home. Amazon's Echos fix/improve nearly every week and you can do things today that you couldn't do last month, yet Google seems to be really slow at adding/improving functionality. And I am not even talking about apps/skills. The fact that Amazon's Echos can do things with Googles products like Calendar that Goggle's Home can't do is embarrassing.Head to head, 60% of the time Echo is able to provide an answer or better answer to Google's Home's 40%. Now no one can see into the future but it already feels like Google is losing interest in really improving their products.Negatives:- Screen should tilt for improving viewing angles- Camera should tlt for better placement options. This would help so you don't have to adjust where you are sitting/standing. For example right now when I video call my wife I see the ceiling fan unless she stands up.- Font size should be adjustable in case you have it across the room (could be fixed via software update)- Audio is very directional, unlike the Amazon Echo (without the screen). I am also not sure that it actually sounds better than the Echo but I will do more side by side testing.-Design is pretty dull. Looks like a Sony Dash (a product from 2009 which means it is 8 years old in design) except not as good! Also reminds me of the old huge rear projector TVs that Sony and other brands made many, many years ago.- Seems like it could/should have a battery built in.- Mesh wifi hubs built in (like Google is rumoured to be working on) would have been awesome.Quick points about competing products:Amazon's Echo: Great device but unless it drops to about half the current price, the show is a better value for all the extra features you get,Amazon's Dot: By far the cheapest way to get started. It does so much for the small price tag but do not plan on listening to music on it without using other speakers. These are nice for less used rooms/spaces.Apple's upcoming HomePod: While Apple makes great products, this device is not really in the same league as the Echo Show. Apple's Homepod will likely sound better than anything else for playing music but will lack most of the features and functions of the Echo line. Get this only if you want a smart speaker for music and the cost doesn't bother you.Google's Home: Fine but my guess is that Amazon will drop their Echo's price (not the new Echo Show) to about the same and it is clearly a better product with better sound, more features and more functions. I have one Google Home and have no interest in purchasing more until they improve it.Google's rumored future device with Wifi Mesh built in: I like the idea but I have been disappointed in the Google home as it stands and Google's mesh Wifi routers are known for being pretty slow so unless they fix that, it seems like a clunker--esp if it doesn't have a screen.Microsoft's future smart speaker: Typically when Amazon and Google are options compared to Microsoft's hardware, it always is the weakest. From my point of view they are making a device not because they love the idea, but so they aren't left in the dust. It will be fine but my guess is that it will be buggy at times and be very limited on functions. I would certainly no preorder it.
