B01J24C0TI	Adds some capabilities to the Echo, but can be underwhelming.	I think there's alot of high expectations for Echo products. The first Echo was obscure and new, and most people weren't sure what to do with besides play music and ask questions, but then it evolved into a system that can be extremely helpful when utilized the right way. Nowadays, I'm used to controlling lights and tv's with Alexa which was a game-changer for me. For Echo Show, it's a nice benefit to have a screen so that you can voice-control functions that require more than a audible response (watch a show, watch youtube, video-call a family member). Although the product itself looks pretty bad, the screen looks nice and doesn't ruin the aesthetic surrounding the object- it looks like a chunky digital photo frame.The software needs to get better- Alexa can lead to a few dead ends when you are trying to get her to show youtube videos or a specific recipe, and it's not intuitive how you get in and out of skills from the screen.It's a learning curve, and I imagine most customers who purchased the Echo Show are existing Echo customers who expect that this device will change their life as much as the Echo did, but are underwhelmed by the capabilities of Echo Show since it doesn't really add as much functionality as you would expect with a screen. B01J24C0TI	Alexa, get me a beer.	This is a great product.  The build quality is top notch, and speech recognition is excellent even in a large, moderately noisy room.  Many of the skills that exist for the Echos don't yet take full advantage of the display, but I suspect this will change quickly as adding a display to Alexa's capabilities is a game changer for these connected home devices.I'm a techie guy and was able to write a home automation skill in one weekend for my custom home automation system.  If you develop software for a hobby or a living, you'll find skill development pretty straightforward and well-documented.I think we're finally seeing signs that home automation with good integration and user interfaces is within reach.  This device is the perfect interface, and one that my non-techie wife and daughter embraced quickly.  They've figured out how to do many things with Alexa before I did, which is a first for any form of technology... ever! "Alexa, get me a beer."I bought two of these with the $100 off deal, and just logged back in to buy two more, but discovered you can only buy two with that deal.  Bummer.Finally, I was initially concerned about having a house full of these plugged in sucking electricity all day.  Lighting up a fairly big display isn't cheap, but somehow the devices manage to only consume 3-4 Watts when sitting idle (measured on the AC side of the power supply and with the display fully lit).  That's quite remarkable.  "Intel Inside" seems to have brought some pretty good power management.	BB	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A31IAKBIEYIWOL/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	13	5	2017/07/05
B01J24C0TI	An Alexa device with a screen that is underutilized.	This is basically an Amazon Echo with a screen.  Amazon Echo has been out a few years and what it can do is well defined (smart home, news, traffic, etc), so this review will be about what's different about the Echo and the Echo Show and that is the screen.Surprisingly the screen is fairly underutilized. Yes it will display the time and weather information as well as interest headlines that Amazon picks, but other than that the screen isn't really used that much.  That said you can use the screen to play videos (YouTube and Amazon Video) as well as Photos (Amazon Photos), so the screen isn't completely ignored, but a lot of the time the screen is simply used to display words that Alexa is speaking.  There are some skills that use the screen, but most do not.The are "pages" which can be set up in the options for things that as far as I can tell never actually display, namely Notifications and Drop Ins.  The Calendar page will show up, but only if there is an event in the next day.  The tips that the Echo Show constantly displays cannot be turned off, which is also annoying.Speaking of the screen, there is no real way to turn it off.  You can ask Alexa to "turn off the screen", but without changing the settings to hide the clock, that simply displays a clock with the backlight still turned on. That is surprisingly bright in a dark room even with the brightness turned all the way down.  Also the screen will turn back on any time the Show hears (or thinks it hears) the word "Alexa".  The screen will also turn itself "off" on its own if it doesn't detect movement or sound, but any movement or using the word "Alexa" will turn the screen back on again.  There is no option to adjust the screen timeout or have it simply not turn on at all, which would be useful for nighttime use.  Keep that in mind if you plan to put this in your bedroom.EDIT: After a recent software update, the screen will turn completely off when asked.  Also putting the Show in Do Not Disturb mode will switch the screen to the ambient clock and disable waking up when it detects motion.There's also a somewhat annoying bug that causes the message notification to get stuck in its current state (either never displaying or always displaying) until the Show is rebooted.  This happens if the home screen setting which tells the Show to display a photo background or simply black or white is changed.  Edit: This may or may not have been fixed as I haven't tested this after the recent software update.Overall the Echo Show is primarily an Echo so it has the Alexa interface, which in itself is an excellent product.  As such the Show is as good as an Echo from a usage standpoint.  Right now there's not enough usage of the screen to warrant paying extra for the Show, but I'm hoping that will change in the future.	Morac	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A3MB2L3K20OWLO/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	1	4	2017/07/05
B01J24C0TI	The best Echo, but is it worth the $50 premium?	The short answer is: yes, this is worth the premium of the regular Echo. Here's why in detail:1) The bright touch screen makes the human-machine communication easier than with an audio-only black box (correction: black cylinder). A quick glance at the Echo Show yields a picture of the artist, lyrics, album art, the weather, or wikipedia info. That picture is worth more than a thousand words. That is obviously exaggerated: the true extra value of the screen is probably a dozen words spoken by Alexa's synthetic voice. Still, that is better.2) The main advantage of the screen is to enhance the existing Echo experience. The new capabilities of the touch screen are also pretty cool. Saying "Alexa play youtube Stephen Colbert" is faster than grabbing a smartphone out of the pocket, followed by some frantic fingering. Echo show is great for short interactions such as news events. It's also possible to watch Amazon prime video, but such longer engagements on a small screen are not the sweet spot. This is Echo Show, not Echo TV.3) It is my impression that the sound quality is a bit better than the conventional Echo. The new Echo Show has 2 front facing speakers that project true stereo sound. The original Echo is mono.4) The Echo Show screen adds colorful eye candy to the kitchen counter. Music is shows wit album art. A nice touch is that the screen dims dark when nobody is in sight. It immediately wakes up as soon as some movement is in its field of view.5) The video call capability is great for setting up a connection with elderly parents. Echo Show is easier to operate than a smartphone and the camera is always in the right upright position. I was pleasantly surprised that it is possible to call the Echo dot in my daughter's room, even though it is on the same account. The system is very easy to setup and convenient to use.After all these positive points, I have to mention one weaker issue of the Echo Show. The original Echo is an industrial design masterpiece: an iconic cylinder made from excellent materials. It will end up in art musea next to iconic Apple and Braun designs. The teardown at iFixit shows that this beauty runs more than skin-deep, with elegant engineering of the inner components. The Echo Show is not at that level. It is not even close with its utilitarian square design and cheaper looking plastic. It looks like any $30 clock radio at first glance. That is a missed opportunity, because the Show will have to be placed in a prominent place in kitchens or the living room.Overall, the Echo Show is a good functional improvement over the orginal Echo. It is a product that is ahead of any competition, while still at a reasonable price point. Kudos for Amazon in pulling this off so well. Echo is a device that Apple should have brought to market, but wasn't able to without Steve Jobs. Jeff Bezos turns out to be a worthy successor of Steve's spirit. B01J24C0TI	Really wanted to love this new one.	Well, let me start off by saying I thought this would be a really extraordinary addition to the Echo offerings, but its at best, so so. I'd say the best part of the Show, is the good sound quality, and since I don't have an Echo, can't say how much better this is than that. $230 will buy you a fairly good laptop these days! I can see where when they come out with gen 4 or 5 we may get wowed,but not yet.  I feel Amazon rushed this out to the market, to avoid being 'scooped' by another company...little thought went into its design or function at the point of this release. If they wanted the first buyers of this device to be beta testers, then they should have sent them along withoutcharge. Who came up with the shape of this thing...shame on them, its ridiculous. My first attempted echo show to echo call proved to me that putting 8 mics into this device was a waste, the caller couldn't hear me clearly unless the device was less than 2 feet away from my face! And not being able to move the camera angle? Why they would allow photos to be placed on the home screen and then not allow the annoying 'hints/suggestions' that block those photos to not be deleted is beyond me. This device has a lot of work that needs yet to be done, and unfortunately much of it should have been done while it was still on the drawing board, not in consumers hands. I expect thousands of these will be getting returned as people wait for them to offer a 'finished' Echo Show at a later date.UPDATE: 7-15-17: I stand by all of my above observations. With the money I saved, I can start looking for a real digital frame, which is the main reason I took a chance on the Show to begin with. B01J24C0TI	Good product- but screen isn't adding that much yet	I was very excited for this product. As an early echo buyer, I pre-ordered this almost the day it came up, assuming that it might sell out. All in all, I was generally disappointed. It seems like a "rushed" product that strove to beat the googles, apples, etc of the world out of the gate with the 1st home assistant with a screen.I will caveat my review (6 days after release) by stating that Amazon still has plenty of time to make updates/changes to the show and hopefully will over the next few months. So, given that,  here are my pros and cons:PROSVideo calls- It can make video calls with phones with the alexa app and other echo shows. I'll admit I haven't used this yet, but I'll also say that I wasn't really looking for a home phone with this purchase. If this feature is important to you, you will probably be happy with the purchase as it is significant. Just bear in mind, that the people you call need the app or the show..Screensaver- It gives you different information as well as ways to use it on the screensaver. One of the challenges of the initial echo device was disseminating information on new features. The screen allows for that and will give you ideas on how to use it, which I think is great, especially with updates.All previous echo functions- They work and are supported by a screen, typically displaying text (big win for the hearing impaired).CONSOverall Poor Video integration- While you can watch just about any prime movie or show (why?) it is fairly challenging to access more summary/news or "snackable" video content. This unfortunately puts the echo on a level similar to my cars infotainment system, which is disappointing.  My initial disappointment came when asking for sports highlights. Alexa delivers scores without much other information and basically displays the box score or what is reading on the screen. Overall, I'd chalk this shortfall to poor or non-existent publisher integrations. This was a great opportunity for amazon to strike deals with major media companies for inclusion on echo (in a similar way to how snapchat has done, they could almost carbon copy their snapchat content). In addition, youtube is integrated into the show, but is very hard to navigate. That said, it will play a reuters news briefing if you ask for the news, which about all I found positive in video.Inconsistent use of touch screen- Sometimes you can, sometimes you can't. Its frustrating and I've honestly gotten stuck on certain screens.Wifi issues- I've heard this in other reviews, so I'm glad i'm not crazy. It seems to have trouble in some cases with wifi connectivity and suddenly you'll make a request to alexa and it'll be in some odd holding pattern. I bought 2 of these (one for my dad) and experienced it at his house, but not at my own, so not sure exactly what is driving the issue.HOLDING OUT HOPE FOR UPDATES IN COMING MONTHS! B01J24C0TI	So far, we like this! [updated]	I got 3 of these when they first came out (there was a promo discount when you bought 2.) My family lives in different parts of the state and we thought it would be nice to interact with them through this AND have the other echo skills (like music, weather, etc.) I have all the echo devices so far except the "echo look" (regular echo, tap, and dot.) Each has its own benefits such as size, sound, portability, etc. The screen is awesome though.I am not sure however if each echo in a different house will need their own amazon account. It is all my immediate family (husband works out of town most weekdays, kids in college, and home.) If they use their own account, they won't have access to the prime stuff since we all share my prime account. But if they all are registered to MY account, how do I call the other one? So far we have only set up one and are unsure what to do with the other two. I may call support to see how this is done and will update my review when I find out. We would also like to use it to check in on our house and cats when we are away, but we don't know how to "answer" it if we aren't there. Maybe we can call our phone answering machine and accept the show call with that voice! ha ha!! That seems like a weird workaround. I don't know if there is an automatic setting to answer a call from another show. That seems nice for checking in on an empty house or for someone ill or something. Of course, you would have to pre-approve calls from certain others, but it seems it should be capable of doing that. Since you can connect to other cameras (they show a baby's room in their video) then you should be able to connect to other Echo Shows without a voice acceptance. There is the IFFT app or "mybuddy" where someone who wants to alert others with just a voice, but that isn't video yet to my knowledge.It works just like an echo using your voice, but also has a touchscreen. I didn't really review here all of the alexa features as that has been covered (a lot!) on the regular echo pages, My review is more about the differences. It scrolls news items and tips on the home screen, but you can turn that off if you ask for "display off" where it only displays a white on black digital clock. Well, sometimes it works...other times it asks "which device" and doesn't understand. I am sure this will be tweaked as the devices rolls out. It is pretty new. The size of the screen is listed as 7" diagonally, but those those like me, (who can't clearly visualize that hypotenuse measurement!) the screen itself is about 6 inches wide by 3.5 inches tall.We have indeed checked weather, asked questions, ordered products, and watched youtube videos on it. We aren't good at searching through youtube yet, but it does give you some suggestions based on your command. I am not sure how much we will use the feature for movies or something since it is so small, it would be nice to ask THIS to control your amazon fire stick or something on your tv or to cast your show. But so far, it doesn't do that.It looks like a black trapezoidal box, and the viewing angle is set. I suppose you could stick a pen or something under it to angle it differently, but again, that is more of a hack than a feature. It doesn't look wall mountable, but more of a counter/shelf thing. I am sure there will be 3rd party wall mounts for this which makes sense for a kitchen or something. The sound is pretty good from such a small footprint. To me, the original big echo has the best sound, but this is a close second. Also, when it is loud (like level 10) this seemed to hear us better to stop than the echo (where you sometimes have to yell to get alexa  on the regular echo to hear you over the music!)I don't always like to be an early adopter of things since version 2 of things is usually better somehow, and I am stuck with 1. But I really liked the idea of this and figured they could just update the software, not the entire device (like they have with tap now being able to turn on with just voice.) I hope they keep reading our suggestions and will consider the ideas of many of the folks who bought these.There really needs to be a forum for this product clickable from the echo device product pages! The only ones I found are on the "kindle forum" part of amazon (https://www.amazon.com/forum/kindle?_encoding=UTF8&cdForum;=Fx1D7SY3BVSESG&cdThread;=Tx20BQ8KTGP9S3Z)  ALL the forums/customer discussions are so hard to find now, that people resort to asking questions on the product pages, and no one wants to scroll through hundreds of questions to find something. If there were a dedicated forum, we could ask questions, find hacks and apps, etc.update: I chatted with customer service to see how to set up different ones of these on the same account, but in different locations. Apparently, it "drops in" in people using the device NAME, not phone number or anything. So I just named them for my family members and successfully connected with them with audio and video. I even dropped in on my cat who was home alone (I probably interrupted her secret alone cat rituals! ha ha!) I sort of like the ability to drop in on my house anytime from another device. There is also an alexa calling feature using phone number of contacts. You can use the Echo Show, Dot, and regular echo with that (only the show will have video, of course.) The main difference I see between the two is "drop in" automatically connects and calling announces a caller and you have to answer or ignore. You have a few seconds of blurry time on the camera to turn off the video for drop in if you want. Info for "drop in" is here:https://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html/ref=hp_left_v4_sib?ie=UTF8&nodeId;=202153130For calling, you can also push the video off icon if you are home dancing naked or something. :D  There are also do not disturb settings so you don't have to worry about someone dropping in on you when you don't want them to! If you are nervous about the camera being there at all, you can always get one of thoseÂ sticker sliding webcam coversÂ and keep control it like that. B01J24C0TI	Good, but needs some tweaks by Amazon to be great	This is a great upgrade from the original Echo, however, there are a couple annoyances and lost opportunities that I hope will be addressed in software updates. First, rotating suggestions about how you can use Echo appear on the screen. They even appear while the Show is doing other things, like on the "now playing" screen while playing music. There is a setting to control them, but you can't get rid of them completely. They are very distracting and unnecessary for some people, and I wish you could turn them off. Next, I'm not convinced that the sound is as good as the original, and there is no way to control the speaker bass or treble. Lastly, there is no option to display a simple monthly calendar on the screen. These are issues that I'm sure Amazon can address, and overall I am enjoying the Show, and it is definitely worth the extra cost over the Echo.	R. B01J24C0TI	Ill probably keep them but Im keeping my options open - I was hoping for all that and a bag of chips	Â Ill probably keep them but Im keeping my options open - I was hoping for all that and a bag of chipsThe main reason I ended up purchasing the Echo Show is because of the integration with Camera feeds. I'm able to view a live feed whenever I want since none of these are on battery.If you dont care about the Echo Show working with the Ring and Arlo products then you can stop reading this review now.Im not getting any motion alerts on the Echo Show with my Ring Products. It seems you have to be alerted by the Ring Chime or your Phone / Tablet that something is happening (motion alert / doorbell pressed) and then you can ask the Echo Show to show you the Front Door / Backyard to see whats going on.Im not sure this is a good thing. I guess if you only have one Ring device then you will be fine but if you have multiple then you wont know which device is currently giving you the motion alert.Ive been leaving an iPad on my nightstand with the Ring app open during the night so when I get a Ring Notification, I could just look over at the iPad and it would automatically pull up the camera feed from the device that was detecting motion without having to touch the iPad or say anything.The Ring app on the MAC is the same way. If you open the Ring app on a MAC and click the X it wont actually close all the way, it will just put an icon on the top toolbar. So whenever one of your devices detects motion, the camera feed will automatically open to show you. You don't have to click on anything.With the Echo show on your nightstand, you will need to hear the Ring Chime or the notification on your phone and then ask Alexa to show you the Front Door / Backyard to see the camera feed. Unless you look at your phone to see which device is detecting motion, I guess its a 50/50 chance you ask Alexa for the correct device.If you do put an Echo Show on your nightstand, you can ask Alexa to DO NOT DISTURB, and she will. This will disable the Drop In feature so people cant drop in on you while in bed. But you can still ask to see the Front Door / Backyard camera feeds.The Drop In feature is pretty good.  Takes 10 seconds or so for the camera feed to become clear so you can see whats going on. B01J24C0TI	Not as revolutionary as the original Echo - more evolutionary.	The Show is the next step in the evolution of the Echo. Not as revolutionary as was the original Echo, it is nevertheless a step forward. While there are bugs and omissions to work out, I am not bothered by software issues, as Amazon has done a great job improving and extending Alexa from day one. As the owner of one of the first Echos shipped, I have had a front row seat to this and fully expect it to continue.My complaints will be confined to the hardware as that will NOT be updated and improved with the next firmware release.My only major complaint is the the Show and thus, it's camera, cannot be reoriented. This angle it sits at is the angle it sits at, unless you use a book or some other workaround to alter it. So, the camera's view is of whatever it happens to be pointing at from where it's placed. I have one on a table beside my easy chair. It's a tall table, so when I do a video chat, the other person has a lovely view of the very top of my head. I also think that having a single button to turn off the camera and microphones is a mistake. I would prefer a second button for the camera, so that the camera could be turned off while still retaining voice usability.The camera should have been pivotable, or better yet, the entire Show should have been made with a adjustable base, to allow for different placement. Perhaps someone could market a rotating mirror that mounts above the camera so that the view can be adjusted. It could also have a black side to manually block the camera for privacy.BTW, I was one of those who were upset at the design when the first photos were released, remarking that it looked like something out of 1960's science fiction, but I have to admit that it grows on you. B01J24C0TI	Not Impressed	Not impressed at all. Great concept but the Touchscreen is limited in functionality. I am returning it and sticking with my Echo.i will wait for second gen.	Rosh	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A2QCDCMGI3YQ03/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	2	2017/07/03
B01J24C0TI	Not Quite Ready For "Prime" Time	Having owned an original Echo from the beta testing period, I pre-ordered ordered two of the devices with great anticipation.  The Echo Show is easier to set up than the original, which is important, because there is very little documentation contained in the nicely designed packaging.  Amazon has successfully marketed this innovative product, and it does what it is supposed to, and does it well.  Consequently, there is little need to evaluate the features that were advertised.  Instead, I will report on some of what is problematic, in my opinion.Despite the 7" display, the Echo Show is primarily an audio device.  The screen is tiny compared with anything but a cell phone, and therefore watching a program beyond a few minutes is a bit of a chore.  The speakers are stereo, yet they somehow sound less full than the mono speakers on the original Echo.  I contacted Amazon to ask how to adjust the band equalizer, and the tech rep told me there was none.  Only volume control is possible, at present.  In that regard, the Show is an unfinished product and hopefully some kind of tone control will be forthcoming soon.The Drop-In feature also seems unfinished to me.  There does not appear to be a method for deleting contacts, which means people on your lists may be able to monitor conversations without much notice.  In my judgement, this represents a serious privacy issue, so be aware that after the initial (and subtle) tones, you may not know that someone is drop-in listening to your Show unit from afar.As a purchasing platform for Amazon, the Show is well-developed, as buying products is (perhaps too) easy.  I imagine that Amazon will be refunding many thousands of of items ordered by accident or by unauthorized customers.I think that Amazon owes its customers a bit of an apology for releasing a product that is not quite ready for prime (pun very much intended) time.  The Show needs a better screen, real audio controls, improved (or some) documentation and a lower price to live up to the hype.Amazon is one of the world's foremost pioneers in technology products.  In my judgement, it has the resources to do better and I expect that it will.	Ithaca Chasma	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/AGOPRLMNHHP7W/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	3	2017/07/03

B01J24C0TI	A little rough around the edges but it's going to be great	The main reason I got this was so I could monitor multiple kitchen timers visually without asking Alexa how much time is remaining on each one. Obviously, it would be easy enough to do by making the font size smaller or tiling the timers horizontally and vertically on the screen (instead of just a vertical list as it is now). Also, the screen seems to go back to the home screen after an amount of time and I wish I could lock it to the timer screen while timers were running, this would be hugely helpful while cooking.The video features are pretty good so far as I'm able to ask Alexa to start a movie from prime video and starts playing effortlessly. The music feature with lyrics is very cool too, very similar to Fire TV.There is a button to digitally disable the microphone and camera, although I wish there was a built in physical shield that I could slide over the camera... for now I'm using a small cutout from a black post it note.I think it's an ideal product for your office desk, in your kitchen or even in a bathroom for getting news and weather during your morning routine. Overall, it needs some work and it's probably a little expensive for what it is right now, but I have a lot of faith that Amazon will cleanup some of the edges, add some of the little missing features and it will be amazing. B01J24C0TI	Wish my mate hadn't bought it	Edit, a few days later: I added back one star. Why? Because the folks at Amazon went out of their way to contact me after publishing this review -- they wanted to talk more about shortcomings and changes I might like to see in the Show. AMAZING customer service, always. She also confirmed that I could hook up my original Echo next to the Show, give it a different wake-word, and use that specifically for playing music, which should help a lot. Also something else that I love about Amazon: They don't just bury bad reviews of their own products, like a lot of companies do. They go to work to improve the product.----------Updating after a few weeks. (My husband bought these, I was happy with the old Echos in our great room and our bedroom.)He seems to like it for some reason. I think seeing the weather is his killer app, or having a photo of our dogs as a wallpaper? IDK. We tried to pull up recipes from online, and Alexa had great difficulty finding them and then the screen kept going to black, which is super not helpful when you're in the middle of a recipe.The sound quality is... honestly, lousy. It's not great even if you're in front of the Show. I'm definitely listening to less music since we got it. But if you are NOT facing the Show, music is just bad, boxed-in distortion. I CANNOT EMPHASIZE ENOUGH that whoever wants the Show to succeed needs to create a decent 360-degree speaker peripheral -- like, yesterday. The Echo is the SOLE reason I migrated all my music over to Amazon, because of ease of voice access, huge access to music I don't own, and it helped that the original Echo's sound was just fine for my purposes. If Amazon had created a screen peripheral to the original Echo instead of making a unit that revolves around a unidirectional touchscreen/speaker, *that* might have been okay.Showing lyrics for songs is iffy at best -- mostly non-working. She'll tell you she doesn't have the lyrics for a particular track if you ask for them. I'm at the point where I wish I could hook up the original Echo next to the Show for the sole purpose of playing music. Okay, and interacting with, because I can see the original Echo's top ring of light from 3 different rooms......and that's gone with the Show. Bad flaw. You know how sometimes you call Alexa's name and she doesn't hear you? You can tell if she heard you on the original Echo. But you don't get any indication if you aren't facing the Show's screen. (Our most-used Echo is on a kitchen pass-thru and gets used throughout a great-room layout, so that's a problem.) The light ring was also a help in getting clued in that the wifi was having difficulties, and if it was trying to reestablish connection after a power fluctuation.I'm hoping we can use the drop-in feature to check on our dogs while we're out and let them hear our voices. Haven't tested it yet. Otherwise, ain't nobody droppin' in here. (Nobody ever really wanted videophones, guys.) Also, the Show should allow you to decide WHICH of your contacts you want it to have, to say the very least.At least having a new unit, PERIOD, did solve several incurable quirks our old kitchen Echo had developed (which the one in the bedroom never did)... for instance, suddenly being unable to recognize artist "Little Feat" and serving up some annoying "His Little Feet Christian Children's Choir" instead ::pokes ears out with forks::But I really kind of hate the Show. B01J24C0TI	Nothing more than a Fire Tablet tied to AC and incapable of the most basic functions.	This thing isn't ready, not even close. I really wanted this to work. I thought, finally, I can use something for video chat and ordering from Amazon and getting information instead of using my smartphone. The setup is easy enough, you get a talk through and display that gets you connected quickly and then the device updates it's software. Everything after that is a disaster, let me explain.The first thing I wanted to do was change the alert word from "Alexa" to something else. I asked Alexa how to do that and was told to go to the Alexa app on the device I wanted to change. Hmmm, "Alexa, go to setup". "Sorry, I can't help you with that". "Alexa, show me the setup screen". Youtube starts up.  One more time. "ALexa, setup".  Ding. (the little sound). A really bad start trying to do something so simple. Then I tried to search for things, nothing way out, like a recipie for baking a Peach Apple pie. Instead of seeing recipes I am asked if I want to load some app for which I have no idea if it allows access to my network, my contacts or any other information. I don't even know if it will cost me additional money. I try it anyway. A bad move on my part. I choose a recipe and want to scroll down to see the directions so I say "Alexa, scroll down". "I'm sorry, I can't help you with that". "Alexa, go down one page". "Ding, nothing.It seems what Amazon did was simply load the smartphone Alexa app onto Echo Show and push it out the door. The whole purpose of using Echo Show is to free up the hands and interact with it by voice and thus bring a new dimension into using Amazon and it's services. It simply doesn't work. Another example. I have several Fire enabled TVs so I should be able to connect them in some way, Amazon says so and so does the initial setup screen which it seems you can never get to again. When it showed all my Fire enables devices and I chose one of the TVs I was prompted to enter the code display on the TV's display. Great except there is no such code displayed. So I go into all the setting for the Fire dongle and no code is there. It is these simple things that are either non-existent or so poorly implemented that there is no way this product is ready for general use.I bought two of these with the idea of buying several more to give to family members. While it works for very simple things like asking about the weather, anything else is pure frustrations. One ore example:I asked "Alexa, what is the stock price for Amazon?" The answer is, "I'm sorry, I can't help you with that"? So I ask for business news and what I get is the same canned display and run through of Reuters news brief that comes on anytime something I ask for has the word news in it. As this doesn't work, the software is obviously nothing more than a copy paste affair, I am returning both Echo Show devices. If I am going to be forced to use three buttons, Power, up and down then I might as well just use a tablet. I expected at least specific software or software that is aware of what device it's running on and then provide services and capabilities to get the most out of that device. As this is now, it is nothing more than a large, very heavy, AC cord tethered 7" Fire Tablet in a desk sized case. No thanks, maybe some time in the future but then everyone else is coming out with better stuff too.Mr. Bezos, are you listening? B01J24C0TI	Good but I'm hoping context recognition improves	After using two of the recently released Echo Shows for a few days, I'm somewhat satisfied. Setup was very easy, and since the Show has a touchscreen, you no longer have to use your phone to get this Echo running. The sound and screen are good. It's really nice to see song lyrics displayed, since we usually play music on ours. Videos on YouTube are fun, and integration with Prime video streaming is nice too. So far I'm disappointed in the context recognition. On my phone, I can see how the Alexa service faithfully understood and transcribed what I said but the device then does something unexpected. Try this yourself by viewing the news items that flash by on the bottom of the display (unless you turn them off). If you don't phrase your request exactly the way it prompts you, there's no telling how it'll respond. For instance, there was a featured news story about Germany and marriage equality. The [correct] prompt displayed was "Alexa, tell me about marriage". But when I asked "Alexa, tell me about marriage equality in Germany", the device instead read a different featured news story about a festival founder being arrested. There were no similar overlapping words. I think maybe it's taking us a while to get used to how the Echo Show requires you to phrase requests in order for it to understand us. We've used an standard Echo for about a year now and enjoyed it We then bought an Echo Dot and were less impressed with the voice pickup (often it understands my wife but not me). The Show seems to hear us just fine, and I'm hoping the voice context will improve. B01J24C0TI	Cool But Still Trying to Figure Out How We Can Use It	Echo Show is a brand new product and still trying to find its role in life. The technology is beautifully employed and a lot of our earlier stated shortcomings aren't in fact true. So its versatility is increasing every day as we learn more about what it can and cannot do.Some examples of misconceptions we held:The camera can be turned offWe believed it couldn't...that only the mic was muted when placed into a sort of standby state. We were wrong. Enabling the 'Mic off' button also disables the camera.We can set it up for our elderly parents use even when they don't use cellphonesWe erroneously assumed that they would need to have a cell phone with Data Plan to use the Show for video calls to us. You do need a cellphone to setup that feature but not to use it.One thing I think the Show has going for it is a very enthusiastic team of people behind it who love technology and want to see it succeed. We received a call from them asking if we had any questions and that call helped us to understand a lot more about how it works and what the  future may hold. That call helped us to realize that much of what the Show needs to improve upon is simply software based and I'm confident improvements will be forthcoming.Examples of this include navigating both YouTube videos and  Amazon videos. Right now the interface leaves a lot to be desired but simple software updates undoubtedly streamline this process in the future.A few things that would absolutely improve Show's versatility for us include:*  The ability to either copy very long Amazon passwords from somewhere or to use 2 Factor authentication so you don't need to use such long complex passwords that are difficult to enter manually.* The ability to sign in to your Google account for tracking your YouTube history* The addition of TV channels similar to those used by Amazon Fire TV....so Netflix, HBONow, etc.* The ability to stream content your watching on Fire TV...so the Show would act as an auxiliary device so you could be watching something on a big screen and not have to interrupt it by going into the kitchen to prepare a snack or meal.There's one feature that all Echo devices are lacking that seems fairly simple to me to  include. It's also one of the most requested features...yet it has never been addressed that I know of by Echo's developers. Alexa needs to be able to conduct Google searches. (Or Bing  searches.)  This would increase its utility be volumes!  Frankly I don't get why this has yet to be incorporated into Echo and I'll be very sad if it never is.	vsajewel	Color: White|Configuration: Echo Show	B010CEHQTG	/gp/pdp/profile/A3229OTKN7P8AJ/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	2	4	2017/07/02

B01J24C0TI	Well worth the upgrade from a Dot or for anyone's first Echo purchase	I've had a couple of days with my Echo Show and overall I really am enjoying the features. Currently, we have 4 Echo Dots around the house (5 Echo devices now) as we've heavily added automation such as lighting, plugs, air conditioners, Nest and door locks to name some of what Echo helps us with. While the Echo Show doesn't really add any value to these devices yet it's still a great step up and Amazon is constantly adding functionality. Cannot wait to see what the Echo Show evolves into!The video feature, especially for video calling is by far my favorite and it's been used quite a bit. Having an intercom like feature to give the ability to communicate with my Echo Dots is pretty sweet! Gone are the days of my wife yelling something from the other room in what sounds like some alien voice that I can never really hear eventually leading to me getting up or her coming to me. Now she just calls.Personally, I love the screen and I think the size is just right. I've heard people commenting about the video quality and/or screen resolution, but this device was absolutely not designed to watch movies on. It is pretty neat however that you can. Where the video ability really makes me giddy is when searching for a movie for movie night. In the past, it was pointless to ask about movie times on the Echo Dot as I'd most always end up on the computer or cell to get more info and/or to see a trailer. Now it's totally Echo Show! Ask for showtimes and a list of movie posters appears. Click a poster and all the information you could want is right there including movie trailers!Everyday activities such as weather, traffic or asking questions are very nicely enhanced with the use of being able to see as well as hear. Speaking of hearing, the audio quality is pretty good as well. It's not Bose, but then again if it were the price would be much higher. Added bass is nice over the original Echo as well. When upgrading from an Echo Dot it is, of course, a huge difference as well as being able to remove the Bluetooth speaker I had connected to the Echo Dot.I love the wallpapers and when using the Amazon photo storage you can have a slideshow with all your favorite pictures in the background. I noticed a few comments about how the photos don't look right, but this is not an Echo Show issue, but rather user error. How so you ask? Well, we pretty much live in a 16:9 aspect ration world now so if taking pictures in portrait mode they simply are not going to fill the Echo Show screen. Landscape mode for video and photos is the only way to go if you ever expect to view your content on anything other than your phone. Since I exclusively use landscape mode when taking photos and videos everything viewed on my Echo Show displays perfectly!I've got to be fair and dim the lights a little on this glowing review as there are a few things I don't really like. First and foremost, the way the device sits, at least how I have mine sitting, leaves a TON of headroom when doing video calls. The device really needs to be tilted forward a good bit to have me framed, but I get it. I'm sure the camera is tilted up for people who might use it in the kitchen or in areas where you might be standing. A simple "kickstand" added to the back would solve this and give the option for a more centered camera view or one looking up. If this bothers anyone else, check out this link for a solution:  https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XCLYL53/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc;=1I stacked the rubber feet 4 deep. One stack on the back left and right side and one stack in the back middle. Perfect camera position for my use (sitting with the Echo Show on a table to my left). Even doing this, the device is still very stable and isn't high enough to make it tilt or fall forward.It's new so there are still some bugs. Recently when my dad calls me from his Echo Show to mine it was ringing on my cell phone instead of my Show. Very frustrating as it had been working just fine. Also, a new notification icon (circle with what looks like a person) has appeared in the upper top right and for the life of me, I simply could not clear this from my screen. A quick call to Echo support and a device reboot cleared up the calling issue and the notification icon should be working in the next update.Lastly, before I turn the brightness back up is the drop in feature. Unless I'm doing something wrong, avoid this feature at all costs! In its current state, if someone is allowed to drop in do not expect any privacy as after a few seconds your screen is no longer blurred to the other person and they can see everything going on! It was my understanding you had to voice accept a drop in but doesn't appear to be the case. Imagine the horror of dropping in on someone doing the nasty or even worse - them dropping in on you!Personally, I think it's another great Amazon product and well worth the upgrade. Will I replace all of my Echo Dots with Echo Shows... no, not at all, but my wife wants one for her area so we'll have at least two!	Valorus	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A2BQYX3VAC63X7/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	5	2017/07/02

I could be wrong about that , but again that goes to the lack of documentation that doesn't come in the box with the Echo Show. Many of the Echo Show's feature are tied into Amazon Prime (music and video come to mind right away) so it appears that you get much more use out of the built in features if you have a Prime account. Leigh	Color: White|Configuration: Echo Show	B010CEHQTG	/gp/pdp/profile/A171G1ZQKW9QV1/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	N/A	4	2017/07/01
B01J24C0TI	Good hardware but the software needs work.	Rather than detail the virtues of echo devices as a whole, which you likely already own, I thought it might be more useful to offer info on what the show does differently than the cheaper echo devices (echo, tap, and dot).  Is it worth the money and space or are you better off with something else?This is an early review, I've had the device since launch, but I will be updating it as things go along.The first thing you notice when unboxing the device is the contrast in weight and angles, the device is heavier and more boxy than other echo devices and resembles a small TV or the earlier internet connected devices like Sony Dash or Chumby.  It's pleasing to the eye and the guts of the device shrink behind the 7" screen and the bottom speakers.  The screen itself is pleasing to look at, there's no prominent light bleed or color issues but it's not anything to really praise.  The lack of OLED, while understandable for the price, is disappointing but only notable when in the do-not-disturb or screen off mode where the screen goes black save for a white time display (and a moon when in DND).  The speakers are really nice themselves though; on par with the regular echo (It fills the space a little less though).The show does all that you'd expect of an echo - answering questions, listening to music, shopping, etc - and a few new things like watching videos (from YouTube and Amazon Video as well as news and trailers), video calls, and new skills that take advantage of a screen (e.g. "Show me the front door" will display video from Nest, Arlo, etc cams that you've called 'front door').  Everything is still controlled with your voice although there are opportunities to interact with touch.  Unfortunately, at this time, the touch interactions feel shallow and often incomplete.  For example, if you get a message a notification pops up that you can tap on and it will display a list of household users and the number of messages each person has but you can't tap on a name to see more information, you have to ask for it to play messages and then when it does it doesn't show you the text of those messages, even when they were sent as text.  It's disappointing and confusing as an interface.Videos look nice and have little load time but the limited services and lack of browsing opportunities limit the use right now.  The recently added calls and drop-in feature really shine here and the slow video fade in is a nice touch for drop-in.  Playing music gets a boost with on screen album art and lyrics if available.  Certain skills get a handy boost from the screen as well providing visual feedback.  Uber and Allrecipies have been my favorites thus far.  Amazon also does a nice job of featuring skills that have been enhanced for the show for you to try out.While not in use the screen generally displays two pages.  One page displays the time, weather, news, feature tips and timers if they're being used, the other just time, news, and feature tips.  They cycle through the display at about 5 seconds and update information periodically.  These screens are customizable in the slightest at this point and it feels like a missed oppertunity.  The information is useful but it'd be nice to limit it to a single page and always have weather and timers up or to change sizes of things for visual impairments.The user interface itself, as a whole, feels poorly designed with sparse details and a complete lack of configuration.  Weather displays the current temp on one page, then high and low on another, then the next 4 days on another, then the 3 days past that on yet another, and finally the RealFeel, precipitation, and wind on still yet another screen.That's not to say the device is bad but when faced with the choice of this or the $50 echo or even $170 cheaper dot you're paying a premium for the screen.  And that premium, at least right now, is of questionable use.  If you're already planning to drop for the cost of an echo the $50 more for the show might be worth the risk but for anyone with an echo or considering a dot then it's a much harder sell right now.  Amazon has shown a dedication to improving these devices though so I've got almost no concern that this will improve but they also introduce new and often cheaper devices as well and I'm not sure what would win out here in a race.  While things like the echo dot are almost at a compulsion level of benefit for the cost this just isn't there, yet.  If you're in the market for a new echo or simply must have video calling/drop-in this is worth the consideration but if you've already covered your home in echos, taps, and dots then you can wait for this to get better or cheaper.Pros:++ Great sounding speakers++ All the Alexa/Echo features you know and love, only better+ Certain skills, e.g. allrecipies, really benefit from the screen+ Amazon features skills enhanced for Echo ShowCons:-- Interface and display isn't customizable-- Display isn't utilized well or at all for some features (e.g. messaging)- Touch interface doesn't run deep- Most expensive EchoThe hardware itself is great, only an OLED screen would offer any marked improvements but the software just has to get better to make more use of  the screen and touch functionality, hopefully with improved interfaces as well.  This is very much an investment in what the future will be for this device and while it's a promising start it's not there just yet.	William B Partridge	Color: White|Configuration: Echo Show	B010CEHQTG	/gp/pdp/profile/ACEB83MWVDWLB/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	3	2017/07/01

Where I love the Echo, I must say this seems like an inferior next gen, heavily considering returning. Screen is very small, AI is limited, couldn't get lyrics without subscription plan. B01J24C0TI	The best Echo yet, especially if you have elderly parents	This was really worth the wait. I bought the Echo Show for my parents, who are elderly, and have a variety of ailments.  Since they have arthritis, and a few other issues, I didn't want them to go and answer the doorbell, just to find it's someone soliciting them to buy random junk. So, last year, I bought and installed the Ring Doorbell Pro in their house, which works very well.  The Ring Doorbell Pro is hardwired and not battery operated. After the skill was enabled, I could tell Alexa to show me the front doorbell and a video feed automatically pops up. You really need a good Wi-Fi router with the Echo show as the video will be jerky since the video is very high quality. If you have a good Wi-Fi router, the video comes up very quickly and runs very smooth. I thought the doorbell would launch the app on the Echo Show automatically, but it does not. You have to initiate the connection yourself. Hopefully this will be an option in the next iteration of this skill. I can think of a whole bunch of ideas for this skill to do, but for a very first implementation, it works great with the hardwired version of the Ring Doorbell Pro.The battery powered Ring products do not work as great though. When trying to connect the Echo Show to a battery powered Ring device, I get a message saying something like, " The camera is asleep and needs to wake up and it could take 30 sec". This happens with my Ring Stickup Camera. So, if you want the best experience, you should buy the Ring Doorbell Pro instead of the battery powered versions.One of my parents just came out of the hospital and sometimes just doesn't have the energy to even pick up a cell phone when we call.  So, we have another Echo Show, just for her, in drop in mode.  This has really worked very well for us since she does not have to fumble and look for her cell phone if we need to call and check up on her. Also, we use to call her cell phone, but then we would find that the phone was not changed enough, so the call would end prematurely, or the call would not go through.  All of those issues have gone away with the Echo Show.  If she needs to call a family member, that's just a voice call away as well.Right now, she can use her voice to call up movie and TV shows on Amazon Prime.  Hopefully, Netflix, and other services, will also be forth coming.  But for now, the shows on Amazon Video will suffice.  I've outfitted my parents house with Homekit products from Philips Hue, Lutron, and iDevices, and all of them work flawlessly with the Echo Show.One feature that I found by accident, that I have not found documented anywhere, is that if you hold down the mute button for about 3 or 4 seconds, than a user interface comes up that allows you to shut down the device entirely.  A user interface that's says "Power Off" come up.  Then you can either hot OK to power the device off or hit Cancel to go back to the main screen.  We use the timer function a lot for preparing medicine and cooking food.  When I set a timer, the Echo Show actually shows the timer on the screen.  Therefore, I donâ€™t have to ask it how much time is left every so often.  I can actually see how much time is left.  This may sound like a small thing, but it's really very helpful.  You can even dismiss a timer with a swipe instead of saying cancel timer, or stop timer, when the timer goes off.The Echo Show definitely isn't perfect.  Even though the camera works well, I wish it could swivel so that you can fine tune the position of it.  But all in all, for the scenarios my parents use it for, it works great for a first release.  The ability to check in on someone that's bed ridden, and can't move all that well, even to pick up a cell phone, makes this a great device to own. B01J24C0TI	The Echo Show Really Performs!	So far it has been a pretty good experience with the Echo Show. I can get my Prime Music with the lyrics on the screen, almost like karaoke, and a full 7 day weather forecast shows when you ask for a weather report.  The Show offers some helpful suggestions in the form of a live screensaver when not in use. When your presence is not detected for a while, the Show goes to a dimly lit black screen and clock with large numbers you can easily see across the room. The only drawback I have encountered so far is, to my surprise, the Show does not have the full functionality of all of the Skills that the original Alexa and the Echo Dot can perform. For instance, when I asked the Show to tune to the Weather Channel, using the Dish Network Skill, the response was to double check my Alexa App for the Skill, but a few seconds later, I asked the original Alexa to perform the same function and it was handled flawlessly. B01J24C0TI	Good device, but not quite there.	I own the original echo, an echo dot, and now the show. You CAN dim the screen by going into the settings, not something that is apparent by just using the device and I have seen quite a few people complain that cannot dim.  I believe it has a built in screen protector that removes the "news" cards that repeat, but I am not sure how it works.  I've had it go to the screen once while playing music and then again when I woke up and came into the living room, I can't even find an option to set a timer.One of the biggest reasons I gave it 3 stars is that Amazon does not include this device in their amazon unlimited music echo subscription.  To those not familiar with that it is a $3.99 version that allows you to stream albums that are stuck behind a paywall.  The echo, dot, tap are all included, but not the show.  This means if you want to listen to new music you will be forced to pay $7.99.All in all it is a great device for the person who wants to have the new "tech toy", but I would wait until it establishes itself more and have more options that relates to the use you want to get out of it. B01J24C0TI	Great potential...needs some work.	I received this item on the release date and I haven't been as excited about any product since the original Echo. Upon plugging this in, I encountered my first disappointment...unable to log in to my Amazon account. On-screen instructions asked me to visit the Amazon help forum but I didn't find any answers there. I tried rebooting and this time around, it says I can't log in because an account already exists. After second reboot, it finally started up and asked to update software. Okay, I guess they haven't worked out all the kinks before pushing this out the door. I'm fine with that.Next, I had some trouble having the Echo Show communicate with my smart home devices. That was eventually resolved when I plugged my old Echo back in. Maybe somehow it needs to communicate through a "primary" device? Anyway, on to the features. The thing I was most excited about was being able to see my camera feeds. This worked ok but there was quite a bit of lag between giving the command and camera feed showing up on the screen. Not so useful if someone rings the doorbell and having to wait 20s before I can see who's there. Then I tried video streaming via YouTube and Amazon. Yes, this works but I'm not going to stand there and watch a full video on this tiny screen. Appears to be more a novelty feature than something actually useful. Also, I'm not a fan of the interface because whenever you stop a video or stop playing music, it doesn't know to go back to the main screen. You have to tell Alexa to go back to home screen. Speaking of the home screen, I can't stand the Alexa help tips that keep popping up. I would hope that they put in an option to turn it off. One feature that I do like is using the Echo Show as a digital picture frame. The disappointing part is that you can only upload 1 photo. I'm sure this can be fixed with a future software update.I want to talk about the camera now. Video calling was supposed to be the killer feature of this device and I want to say Amazon failed miserably here. The biggest problem, also mentioned in other reviews, is the camera angle. It is not adjustable so it's always pointing up to the ceiling. You can't really video chat unless you're close to the device or if you place the device on the floor. This is something that can't be fixed with software and we may just need to wait until the next iteration of the device. Not to mention, the software for calling isn't polished either and it's extremely buggy. Drop-in would only work 50% of the time and calls are successful maybe 30% of the time.Overall, I think the Echo Show has potential but needs some improvements. It does everything the original Echo does so I don't consider it a worse product. I see it as a device that will get better over time and worth the extra $50 if you were considering an Echo device anyway. Speakers are comparable and build quality is good. Although the Echo Show did not live up to my expectations, I would still recommend this product.	Eric L Lau	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A2NIZL8J3E9NCM/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	3	2017/07/01

B01J24C0TI	The future: we're not there yet.	I use Siri, Cortana, and Google Assistant fairly often in different settings, and I'm left wondering if perhaps the bar in my head is set a bit too high for Alexa.Can she lock my front door? Yes. But remembering the specific skill command is a bit unnatural. Instead of "Alexa, lock the front door," it's "Alexa, tell Smartlink to lock the front door." And there's no concept of "Alexa, tell Smartlink to lock all doors." Nevermind the fact that neither the locks nor the system they're connected to are called "Smartlink". Similarly, you can't say "Alexa, set the temperature to 72." With a Nest thermostat, you have to tell her the name of the thermostat. Minor, minor things, I get it. But they seriously crimp your "I live in the world of tomorrow" style when you can't just say "Lock the front door." or "Set the temperature to 72."Can she answer questions? Yes, if you ask her the right way. Even then, she doesn't understand context like the other assistants. So, when I asked "How old was John Lennon when he was shot?" Alexa told me that there's a new patch that can be applied at home as an alternative to flu shots.I rephrased. "Alexa, how old was John Lennon when he died?" which got her to start spouting off a synopsis from the Wikipedia article, where she eventually got to the question I asked. The other assistants tell you that he was 40.It's cool, but in a nerdy "this is probably more effort than it's worth" kind of way.Getting past Alexa and to the Echo Show hardware, there are some nice aspects. The screen is reasonably clear for the price, and the sound quality is decent. The design has a cool look to it, but in more of an 80's futurist aesthetic. That's about where it ends, though.Right off the bat, not being able to completely dim the display is a really, really dumb design choice. You can set the Echo Show to go into sleep mode through the Alexa app, and that will make the screen go to black with a white clock, but it's still rather bright. If you need darkness to sleep, you're not going to want this in your bedroom. Speaking of dumb design choices, it's even dumber that you can't just tell Alexa to go to sleep. (The command Alexa expects is "Alexa, do not disturb.") Update: This *can* be accomplished through setting up a DND schedule in the Alexa app on your phone, and then by turning the clock off through a series of screen taps through the Settings menu -- on your device that's supposed to be controlled by voice.)When the Echo Show isn't in DND mode, the attraction screen constantly scrolls through a bunch of junk, with little to no context. It gives as much precedence to what I've put on my calendar as it does to inviting people to ask how tall Mount Everest is, or that Jay-Z has a new album. I'd understand if I'd ever expressed interest in Mount Everest, or if I had ever purchased a Jay-Z album from Amazon. But it's just random. Right now, the one I put in the kitchen is showing me pictures of a starry night, and it's 10 a.m. Thanks?Watching content on the Echo Show works, and I guess if you wanted a media consumption device somewhere between your phone and computer, it makes sense. Maybe in a kid's room? I dunno. It's one of those things that you *can* do, but I have a hard time envisioning many times when you would want to. In the kitchen, if you could do "Alexa, show me how to filet a fish" and have a video pop up that showed you how, that would be great. That's actually what I was expecting. Instead, she says "Sorry, I couldn't find the answer to your question."The drop-in function is super interesting, but even that can get infuriating."Alexa, drop in on my other Echo Show""Which contact or device do you want to drop in on?""Bedroom" (My devices are named "Kitchen" and "Bedroom")"I don't see that contact.""Alexa, show me my devices.""For instructions on how to control your home, look at the Help page in your Alexa app.""Alexa, what devices do I have?""For instructions on how to control your home, look at the Help page in your Alexa app."Great. My Echo Show won't show me its own help documentation -- not that I wanted to read it in the first place.So, what you wind up with is this amalgam of different products, where the Echo Show can do all sorts of stuff, but none of it very well. At this point, I'm starting to wonder how long it'll take for the Echo Show to be little more than a glorified picture frame in everyday use. On the bright side, you're going to see at least two in Warehouse Deals soon.	Kevin Nicholls	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A3U41ZL33SS92P/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	5	3	2017/07/01
B01J24C0TI	Echo Show Debut Disappoints And Comes Up Short	Ordered two Echo Show devices. Disappointed with the engineer's software that does not allow one to cancel the video during setup. But that is minor compared to the perpetual display of skill categories and "Try" examples which can not be turned off except to limit the display from continuous to static. Contacted Customer Service who admitted the product was so new he did not know if there was a fix. He referred me to technical support, and that individual, meaning well, was equally unsure except to assure me that a software fix would be forthcoming and he would convey my experience. He also assured me that the perpetual display rotation of categories and Try suggestions would terminate after 30 minutes. Left both devices "on" over night, and the software behavior displayed the same after several hours. Also, in the quick setup, directions state the unit turns itself on when walking into the room or upon hearing "Alexa", which in my experience never occurred. I read the manual provided in the Echo App, the quick start guide and scrolled through the settings available when swiping down from the top of the display screen and none of the settings allowed one to stop the display of categories and Try suggestions except to make the display stop progressing hence a static category and Try suggestion. Or one can turn the display off along with mic/camera. Apparently based on reviews for this product, many purchasers find the Echo Show acceptable or excellent. I never argue with perception. The software is amateurish and the interface is unacceptable. Once I determined how limited the settings were designed to be, I arranged to return both devices. I would have loved to reach a different conclusion but the Echo Group designed in my opinion an expensive device that does what the Echo does but with a screen and a most annoying interface. Not what I expected or would accept. For those who are enjoying their Show, I am happy for them. B01J24C0TI	WARNING!  Calling and Messaging can ONLY be setup on your newer phones!	I just completed a chat session trying to setup the Echo calling and messaging.  BUYERS BE FOREWARN!For this feature to work, you MUST HAVE either an Android phone or iphone.  And it must not be an older version of Android OS or iphone (Windows phone will not work).  The ONLY way to setup the calling and messaging feature is to install the Alexa App on the compatible version of Android phone, or iphone.  If you have an older version phones, you're screwed.  There is currently no other way to setup the calling and messaging.- You cannot set this up using Alexa App on tablets- You cannot set this up on Windows--> you can ONLY set this up on compatible Android / iphones.What this means is, if you simply want to do Echo to Echo calling, you're screwed.  Echo to Echo / Drop In calling cannot be setup unless you install the Alexa App on a compatible Android phone or iphone.  I'm sure they work once you are able to set it up; but that's the problem...you will not be able to set it up unless you have a newer phone (which I do not have).I hope I made my point clear enough; because this was not listed as a requirement in their promos.  I pre-ordered two of these based on their video promo, and was very excited when I received them.  Now, I am very disappointed.	Danny	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/AYCO39W76G47N/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	11	1	2017/06/30
B01J24C0TI	Day 1 review: I liked my Echo. I like my Echo Show even more.	Day 3: Alexa gets stupid or loses functions?Since I made a point of noting the ability to browse Pandora channels in my Day 1 review, I have to note that, two days later, this function has  suddenly disappeared. Now "Alexa, show me my channels on Pandora" gets the response "Sorry, this isn't supported on this device." Drop the word "me" and say "Alexa, show my channels on Pandora" yields "What do you want to hear?".---------------Day 1: First day with the echo show.  I'm pretty pleased with it.  Some observations that I think have not been hit in most reviews:* Sound quality seems similar to that of the Echo cylinder.  Good for a desktop listening experience, not impressive if you want to fill a room with sound.* The Show does have an ambient light sensor (using the camera?) so that the screen dims as the room lighting goes down. When I darkened the room at night to work at my PC, the Show display dimmed to the point where I could just make out the time, and not the background photo at all.* Much has been made of the Show displaying lyrics when playing Prime music.  That doesn't appeal to me, but when playing music from Spotify, Pandora, and My Music on Amazon, the Show displays the song title, artist name, album art, and a progress indicator.  That's really nice when listening to playlists - I was always asking my Echo cylinder "Alexa, what's that song?"* Alexa has always been weak at recognizing the names of some of my Pandora channels. With the show, if Alexa doesn't recognize the name, I can ask it to display my Pandora channels and select them from the Show touch screen, It's good to have a fallback that does not require me to pull out my phone and fire up the Alexa app, then work my way through multiple screens to get my selection.* Some newsfeeds are now accompanied by appropriate photographs.* You can set the Show to use an album from Amazon Prime Photos as a slideshow when the device is inactive.  AFAIK, other photo servers cannot be used.	Sandbagger	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/AR86992NOVBQX/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	10	4	2017/06/30

B01J24C0TI	Muddy voice quality, poor audio, and terrible software - not the Amazon quality we've come to expect	I have several generations of Kindle Fire tablets, and both the Echo and Echo Dot, all of which which have proven to be impressive devices. The Echo in particular has proven to be very useful for controlling Smart Home devices such as the TP Link smart switches. All of these devices have excellent audio quality for their size. From that experience I was expecting the Echo Show to be of similar quality, and the initial impression in unpacking its well crafted shipping box seemed destined to bear that out. Unfortunately, I did not find it to live up to expectations for reasons I will outline.In powering up the Show, I was immediately impressed by screen quality and the ease of the setup process. As an initial test I simply asked for weather, which produced a very nice display. The Show also responded well to voice command, so it looked certain to be the equivalent of an Echo enhanced by a display.I have a Ring doorbell, a Smart Home device that requires a video display, which was a motivator for acquiring the Show. As advertised the Show displayed what my Ring doorbell sees, but that's the extent of what it could do (e.g., the Show couldn't answer the doorbell, or talk to whoever was there, something that still required my smart phone, so why bother). I would lay that obvious inadequacy at Ring's feet, but none the less a disappointment.Shrugging the Ring experience off, I next tried stuff that's purely Amazon's, starting with Kindle books. The Show listed my Kindle library as a row of book covers, but a recent purchase was omitted for some reason. What I immediately discovered is that you can't actually read a book on the Show. If you have the audio version, the Show will read it to you, but doesn't display the companion text (which is a feature on the Fire). Worse, the sound quality is awful, being muddy and echoey, making it hard to understand the narration. In an independent reaction, my wife asked why the voice was so muddy, a description I soon recognized applies to the Alexa voice as well.Since voice and music are two different audio animals, I next asked the Show for my music library. Let me say here that the music software is simply bizarre. If you select an album it grabs one of the songs and that's the only one you can play. If you return to the home screen and ask for your music again, then select the same album, it comes up with a different song to be played. There is no way to access the contents of an album. What the heck? While the display is pretty, it is almost useless. Worse yet, in playing something demanding for an audio system (a movement it grabbed from my Vivaldi Four Seasons album), the results were screechy and unbalanced, close to unlistenable; i.e., it would appear that the unintelligible book audio and Alexa's muddy voice are symptomatic of a generally poor audio system.I had really wanted to like the Show, but it simply is not what it purports to be. It looks good, and feels solid, but it's what's inside that counts.  The Show falls well short on both software and sound quality. I will credit the unit for having an excellent display and easy set up, but as for the rest, ugh.  I initially thought I would wait for software upgrades to fix things, but I don't think there's anything that can be done to correct the audio deficiencies. I'm sending it back.	C. Winton	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/ARC5ASW9CUAGP/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	9	2	2017/06/30
B01J24C0TI	Half-Baked release -- especially with RING DOORBELL integration	I was very excited about having the opportunity to own the new Amazon Echo Show. I bought two of them.While the build quality is very good, it's the lack of "completeness" that makes this device as great as it could be.For starters, let's begin at the home screen.  Throughout the day you are barraged with calendar reminders, weather and timer events.  All of that is good. However, then Alexa tacks on all these "tips" for you to try which just clog up the screen.What Amazon should have done is allow you to make your own personal news feed based on news sources.  These could display throughout the day instead of having Echo advertisements pop up.Next, security cameras.  While Alexa does a good job of tapping into my Nest security cameras, it's the RING DOORBELL that gives me the most frustration.  While it will show my front door on command (with a good few seconds of delay to bring up the video), there is no way to communicate with the person at the door.  How this kind of omission was made between RING and AMAZON is astounding.  This is a major drawback to having RING compatibility.Another problem is making video phone calls.  One must have a cell phone in order to be eligible to make video phone calls.  This makes absolutely no sense.  My mother is elderly, has no cell phone, but has this cool Amazon Echo which is an internet device with camera and she can't make a phone all to another Echo device?  How is something like that possible?The Echo Show also has a habit of slowing down.  That's right, there have been many times where the device starts to lag.  I would ask Alexa a question or give.a command and there would be a 5-10 second delayed response.  Sometimes, Alexa will just time out and not answer at all.It really looks as if this product was rushed out to market with some serious compromises made.  When it works, it works mostly well.  I love the fact I can tell Alexa to show me any camera in my home upon command.  I also enjoy playing Jeopardy with on-screen graphics.Perhaps I am being too harsh on a product that is still basically new, but I thought it fair to let prospective buyers know what kind of issues they are in for. B01J24C0TI	There IS a User Manual	Just set up my Echo Show last night so I'm not ready to write a full review yet.
