B01J24C0TI	It is what it is - and it's awesome. Having a screen is so much better.	I've had the original Amazon Echo since it was first released. I've since acquired a couple of Echo Dots, and have turned my home into a formidable robot house. Nest thermostat, Hue lights, etc etc. And I'm able to walk around anywhere in my house, control all my gadgets, get the weather, add things to a shopping list, etc. with my lovely Echo devices. Having been thoroughly impressed with my Echos so far, I decided to bite the bullet and add the Echo Show to the family. I wasn't sure if it would find it's place or even if the new 7" Touchscreen would prove useful. Turns out, it certainly will and it definitely is.You have to realize what this product is, and I think that if you've watched any of the informational ads/videos Amazon has put out for this product, you should have a perfect idea of that. It's the original Echo, in a much boxier format, with a touchscreen. That's it guys. It's not going to suddenly be able to mow your lawn for you, trim your beard or give you a haircut (or anything else that involves scissors or ridiculous expectations). However just by trying a few of the 'Things to Try' written on the nifty little card included with the Show, I quickly realized how much nicer having the screen is going to be. Examples:1) I use the Alexa shopping list often. Now I can ask to SEE my shopping list, and even make edits right there on the Show, without having to open the app or go online.2) Exact same thing with my To-Do list. Maybe others don't have any issues with this, but I despised not being able to remove/edit items without having to open the app.3) Every morning when I request the weather, I now see today's forecast as well as the next three days. I love that. Also, the current weather and time is now displayed on the screen at (almost) all times!4) On that note, I ask Alexa what time it is way too often. Maybe this one's just personal due to my lack of clocks in the house, but being able to see the time is a plus. I know I know, a $1 clock has the same functionality. I get that, it's just nice.5) Want to SEE movies playing near you? SEE restaurants near you and their information (open times, reviews, etc)? Now you can, and it's much nicer than listening to Alexa's (lovely) voice read it all out to you.6) Video calls. It may take a while to catch on, but it's a huge selling point trying to be pushed by Amazon. Once more people have Shows, I can see it being an amazing feature. Even if it's just members of your family or ones close to you - being able to just ask to video call and see their faces so easily is pretty awesome.7) SEE your timers. I constantly use Alexa for timers when cooking, etc. but it's a little annoying having to constantly ask 'Alexa, how much time is left' when I want to know how much longer before I can stuff my face with chocolate chip cookies. Now the timer(s) can be seen right on the screen.8) SEE your calendar and your upcoming events. It's much nicer than just hearing them listed out slowly and awkwardly.9) SEE more things.I know the above isn't groundbreaking. But honestly, this isn't meant to be a groundbreaking device. Besides the Video Calling, this is essentially the Amazon Echo with a touchscreen. The benefit that I see, as shown in my list above, is that the things that you used to do on the Echo are now greatly enhanced by having a screen to SHOW you things. It may seem silly to some, but for only $40-50 bucks more than the original Echo, I wouldn't hesitate to purchase the Show.Oh and one more thing. The speaker on this thing is fantastic. Maybe not so for you audiophiles, but for it's size and purpose, it's fantastic. The microphone is also proving to be the best yet. Alexa has perfectly understood nearly everything I've asked so far, with even better accuracy than my original Echo/Echo Dots.The decision is yours. Do you think being able to SEE things on your Echo would be helpful? Do you use the calendar, shopping and to-do lists often? Are you interested in Video Calling? If yes to any of these, or if you are a newbie to the Echo family and are looking for your first Echo device, I would definitely recommend you picking up the Echo Show.But hey, what do I know. I'm just an average dude.	Average Dude	Color: White|Configuration: Echo Show	B010CEHQTG	/gp/pdp/profile/A1PVRD76I3ERQA/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	3	5	2017/06/30
B01J24C0TI	Not fully realized	There are things I like, and things I don't. Setup was easy, but overall I think the product is not great. Those photos are pulled from my Prime Photos library, but it doesn't appear to allow selection of a specific album. Not great. Also, the amount of time the photos are displayed before moving to the next also seems to be unchangeable.The recipe thing could work (it pulls up stuff on Allrecipes), but I don't think I can easily catalog my own recipes and have it dictate specific steps. Also, the screen turns off after a little bit, so then I'd need to touch the thing or figure out how to get it back to my previous view. Also, in order to use it in the kitchen I'd need to unplug it from its usual location and find a good outlet for it. I'm not going to do that. I don't want it in the kitchen all the time due to lack of counter space. The Show won't function without being plugged in, so it's really not as portable as pretty much any other screened device that I own. This is not only inconvenient for the kitchen aspect, but if I wanted to use it for the video calls I need to set it up in an appropriate area and commit to it. Some degree of battery powered portability would have been great.The voice recognition is fantastic, and the Echo responded well to my seven year old (who is not the most clear speaker). I asked Alexa to restart the episode, but she can't do that. You can't even touch the screen and restart the episode, it simply isn't an option. You can't even jump to the next episode. It's strange. B01J24C0TI	Potentially great next gen Echo, very useful, with one glaring design flaw that impacts usability.	Edit July 5, 2017:Just found out that the Show does not support bluetooth headsets.  Another pretty glaring omission.  For a device that supports calling (video or audio) it absolutely should support bluetooth headsets.  Because of this you are FORCED to have calls where anyone can hear the call whether you want them to or not.  If you are the type of person that thinks anyone around you should be able to hear both sides of a conversation then this won't be an issue.  If you feel that you might want the other callers audio to be private... you are out of luck.Hopefully this will be addressed by Amazon at some point.Original review:So far the Show is proving to be a useful device and the feature set over the regular Echo's is great.  Video calling works wonderfully and the display (and capabilities it brings) is a welcome addition.That said there is one glaring issue that I expected to be a problem and I'm surprised Amazon released the product with this design.The camera angle.Amazon I have to wonder if you did much beta testing of the product or really thought through the design.  You have a device that can be used for video calling AND as a "room monitor" using the drop-in feature to view another Show's camera on demand... the problem?  Any NORMAL positioning of the Show results in a very limited view of the room... because the camera is pointing too far up!  This design flaw is so obvious I cannot believe you released the product like this.  It could have been great but now it's mediocre.  You should have made the camera have a tilt capability to point it down lower.  This is a glaring issue that will frustrate many of your customers.Another potential issue is that it appears you can only pair bluetooth speakers, not headsets, so if you want to make a video call to another Show you are forced to have audio through the speaker.  I have only tested with a Plantronics Voyager 5200 so far, which is a bluetooth headset (mic and earpiece) and it would pair but would not function.  I suspect the bluetooth headset profile is not supported.  This is a shame if you want to do video calls but have the audio be more provide (ie in a home office setting).I'm sure the device will improve over time and in spite of the above issues I am happy with the device so far.  I'll be testing with a audio only bt headphone soon to see if that works as opposed to a bt headset.	K. B01J24C0TI	Great alarm clock and knowledge tool for pre-typing kids. Home intercom too.	I have used the original Echo for many months as well as the Google Home. I upgraded to the Echo Show to replace my kid's alarm clock and it works very well for that purpose. You can read the time anytime as the clock is always-on.ALARM CLOCK-Setting alarms is easy - "Set daily alarm for ...". Viewing all the current alarms is easy - "Show me my alarms".-Setting timers is also easy - "Set timer for....".-Much easier to set alarms compared to the old-fashioned type. Kids can easily set their own alarms and timers.FEATURES-Does spelling and math. My kids are constantly asking me to spell words and solve simple math problems. Now they can ask Alexa "What is 100 times 100" and both hear and see the answer.-Watching Prime videos directly on the device. Say "Just Add Magic Season 1"and then use the touchscreen to view the desired episode.-Asking any trivia question. "Show me a picture of a Titanaboa".-Plays music and displays lyrics for some songs in real-time. Could function as a simple karaoke player. My kids like to hear lullabies as they go to sleep and Alexa has a good lullaby station - "Play lullabies". (Note: If you mistakenly say the singular "lullaby", it plays a single song called Lullaby.)INTERCOM-It is not obvious, but I managed to figure out how to use Alexa as an in-home intercom. You need to activate the "calling and messenging" feature which requires your phone number. Then you command "Drop in on (echo name)" and a video chat will start up. Pretty cool.-There are no customization options for the intercom. You can't easily reject or block incoming chats. There is no instant mute button either. So if you are doing something important like on a business call on your cell phone, an incoming Echo call could interrupt you.BUILD QUALITY-The fit and finish is immediately impressive out of the box. The entire unit has a nice heft that makes it feel like a quality device.SCREEN-The screen resolution is excellent for text - no pixelation visible. For videos, the resolution could stand some improvement though.-Love the touchscreen.SOUND-Quality is plenty good and can get very loud. Speakers now face directly toward you unlike with the previous Echo and Google Home.-There are hard volume up/down buttons but unfortunately no mute button.COLORS-I got one in both black and white. The black version has a more cohesive appearance because the front of the unit (which is black) matches the rest of it. The finish of both is good so there is no bad choice here.ANY MISSING FEATURES?-It would be nice if I could create separate Echo accounts of each of my kids' Echo's. That way my kids can't access my personal info (schedule, shopping list, make calls, etc.). I would also like to set restrictions to content based on age.OVERALLThe Echo Show is basically a tablet computer with Alexa-capabilities built into a very nice display case with speakers. The first thing I thought when I used the device is "The future is here". The build quality is impressive especially given the relatively low price. For pre-typing kids, it is a useful information retriever because it responds to voice commands.There are some improvements that could be made. I wish there was a much more robust customization ability for all its features which is especially important if you have multiple Echos around the house for multiple family members. The resolution is good but could be better for videos.All in all, this is an impressive futuristic device. Adding a touchscreen to the Echo makes a huge difference in interactivity, usefulness, and fun. At worst, it is the future of alarm clocks. At best, it is a multimedia entertainment and knowledge tool with intercom ability.	Gcat	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A2507ZYWGMY9BK/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	2	5	2017/06/30

B01J24C0TI	A new part of my Amazon Family!  Now the SHOW!	Today I added 2 new members to my growing Amazon family of Echo products.  The Echo Show.  This brings my totals to (2) Echos (6) Dots (3) Fire TVs (1) Tap and (1) Dash Wand and several Dash Buttons.  I have developed this ecosystem to run my smart house from top to bottom which includes WeMos, Philips Hue, Netgear Airo, Logitech Harmony and Nest.When the Echo Show was first introduced on the Amazon site I was thinking this would be the replacement for the original Echo products but after watching the videos and thinking about my strategy on placement I realized they are complementary, not replacements.  I went ahead and pre-ordered 1 in black and 1 in white.  The idea that I'd use the black one in the bedroom with the ability to be an alarm clock and a way to get my news before getting out of the bed and the white one in the kitchen to do routine kitchen choirs and add things to my shopping lists.  This means that I need to find new homes for the items in those locations - not really a hard task now that Amazon has improved the E.S.P. within the devices.  I will be able to put a Dot in the garage and move an Echo to the lanai.I am including pictures of all of the packaging, details, colors, assessories for each of the new Shows.  All of these pictures are taken by me and are not professional in any way.  If you would like additional pictures please let me know and I'll try to put more up.SETUP (number 1):  Once I unpacked my Shows I started getting the first one setup.  I ran into a couple of problems right off the bat because you setup the device right on the screen and not using the Alexa app.  It prompted me to connect to my network and that was easy.  Then it asked me for my Amazon credentials so I tried to log in and kept getting a warning over and over so I double checked my password to make sure I was using the right one.  I let it sit for about 30 minutes thinking it might be updating in the background but everytime I tried to log in I got the same thing.  I went to the Amazon website and looked up my devices and it showed both of my Echo Shows - so I went back and unplugged the device and plugged it back in and voila - it worked!  The first disapointment was it needed to update right out of the box, but most new products do this now so I waited for the update to finish and install and then Alexa started talking to me!  She was ALIVE!  There is a video at the start that you are kind of forced to watch but you can drag the progress bar to the end to skip over it.  She came up and showed me the time and started giving me suggestions right away!SETUP (number 2):  This one worked like a champ right out of the box.  Not sure if it was due to the first one hanging up or not but I plugged it in and connected it to my internet and she asked me if I was "David" and once I said yes it ran the update, played the video and things were grand!So I started to play with my new toy.  Asked for a few of the usual things, dimmed some lights, changed the A/C with Nest, played a song from a playlist.  Everything worked as expected.WHAT I LIKE:  This is a cool little box with a video screen.  It is touch sensitive and you can provide some input that way or just say "Alexa" and she is ready to listen to what you want.  The folks at Amazon have updated her voice a bit and made it a little smoother (this was on all my devices about a week ago) and her speach pattern is a bit more (human?) realistic.  I knew this would have a bigger footprint because the moved the sound to the bottom and gave it bigger & better audio.  It sounds really good!  Not top of the line sound but better than you would expect from a smart device on your kitchen counter.  I like it but I know there are going to be people out there that bash the sound quality but for the price I think it is on point.  The video screen quality is also good.  The touch is very responsive and works as expected.  You have 3 buttons at the top to mute and volumn + and volumn - if you don't feel like barking the command to turn it up or down.WHAT I DONT LIKE:  This is tough but I know I will find a few things that are not quite up to what I was expecting.  I just haven't found any yet.  I was a bit upset when setting up the first one but quickly forgot about that once it was up and running.  As with all new technology you just need to be patient.  I wish there were more color options but I'm sure a 3rd party will come out with "skins" so right now you have Black or White.  White works well in my kitchen and black is fine for my bedroom.  I do wish that when you ask for the news in the morning while still in bed it would be accompanied with video but right now it is the same news update I had - audio only.I'm looking forward to everything Amazon will do with this new toy.  The smart toys are now available from all the major providers and they all do things a bit different.  I invested in Amazon because they were first to marked and I was a beta tester for the original Echo device.  I think I will stick with my Amazon ecosystem or "Family" because as I mentioned earlier I own about everything they have released and everything is at a better price-point.  I'll keep my audio equipment for playing audio and my toys to run my smarthome.  Almost everyone has parternered with Amazon so it is getting easier to do most anything with an Echo!I hope this review helps you make an informed decision!  I'd be happy to answer any quesions you may have so just look me up and let me know.  I will update this review over time as things change (the good and the bad).  For now, I'm going to enjoy my Echo Show and see what fun things I can do! B01J24C0TI	Jury still out on the added screen	I bought the original Echo the day it came out.  I always said if it had a screen it could be so much more---I'm still waiting for the more part after having the Show for a few days.  Like the original Echo when it first came out, it took a while and some updates to reach potential.  This Show still needs those updates.  First thing to note is that it's not very customizable.  You're very limited with the settings.  You can change the background pics and a couple of the scrolling options, but that's about it.  I was expecting more of a tablet experience, but now as I'm typing this it is more like my Fire tablet where you don't have the same ability to customize like you would a standard Android Tablet.  I'm just very disappointed in the limitations.  I was hoping that you could change the screen to show like a weather station, etc.  Just more options.  As others have stated, there is a constant message that gives you suggests to "Try" on the screen.  You can hide this, in a way, by turning off the scrolling and just keeping it on your calendar, which we use Google calendar linked to the Alexa app.  I don't mind the "Try" scrolling right now because sometimes it's good to see what other things it can do.  But I could see wanting to turn this feature off at some point....but you can't.....right now.  Maybe an update will cure that.The next pet peeve was just how to get around and use the thing.  Thankfully, CNET has a good write up on their web page on how to use some of the main features and set up your Echo Show, other Echos and the Alexa app on how to use the camera remotely.  There was little to no guidance on these features and you really have to explore the thing.  I had to figure out on my own to try "Alexa, go to the settings screen" to get to settings.  For a while I was trying "Alexa, go to settings" and she responded, "Hm, I don't know the answer to the question I heard" quite a few times.I want to say that it seems she can't hear as clearly as my original Echo.  Others have mentioned that many times, the light turns blue and....nothing...literally no response, which is odd because she usually tells you she couldn't hear you or doesn't understand.  But it's literally nothing with me standing right in front of her...er...it..  :)Lastly, so far, the camera.  This thing is an odd shape to begin with because they didn't put chintzy speakers in it.  But since they put the face at an angle, the camera also faces upward.  So using this on a side table about waist high, when you drop in, you see mostly ceiling.  You can't see anything below about the 3.5-  4 ft level.  So if you are dropping in on your grandkids, well, you won't be able to see them.  I would only see the forehead of my 7 year old son, who is slightly tall for his age.  They should have kept the camera angle at least straight ahead and level and not the same angle as the face.  Now if I want to use it to drop in while I'm out of the house, I have to stack a few kids books under the back end of it to make the camera face straight ahead so I can see kids, pets, state of the house, etc...This seems to me like the developers only thought that people would be standing right in front of it, faces 2 ft away, standing and staring at the camera for this to really work as a "drop in" feature...that or they have a preference of staring at ceilings.So....those are my initial thoughts.  I gave it a 3 which means "I like it" which may seem contrary to what I put above, but I bought this knowing there would be updates to help it's functionality.  The 3 is based on my past experience with the original Echo and that Echo growing into our daily usage.  I expect the same for this...except for the camera issue, the fix for that might be some kind of mount that makes it face forward.	GA GN	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A24XPLK7R7PK12/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	10	3	2017/06/30
B01J24C0TI	I absolutely love the Echo Show	I absolutely love the Echo Show!  Some thoughts:1. The screen is not too bright for use in your bedroom as an alarm clock.  Go to settings on the device. Tap display. Make sure Ambient Clock is turned on. Set Brightness Level to about 1/3 and make sure Adaptive Brightness is turned on.  Then use the Do Not Disturb feature (you can schedule this feature for every day at certain times, turn on manually from the screen, or turn on with your voice)  This is how I have mine set and I have no issue with the brightness level at night or during the day.2.  The screen size is perfect for your desk, kitchen counter, or nightstand.  Some people have commented that the screen is small for watching movies or television shows which is true.  But remember, this not meant to be a TV.3.  I am glad Amazon first came out with the Echo with no screen.  This forced me to get used to using my voice.  That took time to get used to since most of us are used to tapping on screens.  That being said, remember this is a voice activated device first, not a tablet.  That is why there are not many options to use the touchscreen.  However, I'm sure in the future Amazon will be adding more touch screen options.4.  Amazon Echo Remote pairing - setup is different than on the other Echo devices.  Instead of going in the app to set up - go to Settings on the Echo Show, then go to Device Options, scroll down and you will see the Pair Amazon Echo Remote option.5.  Having a screen enhances Alexa.  For example, ask for the weather today and Alexa tells you but also shows you more weather info for the week.6.  I also purchased two Arlo Q cameras to work with the Alexa Show.  Setup was easy and the cameras are working seamlessly with the Show.  It takes about 6-8 seconds for the cameras to pull up on the Show but that was expected.  It takes my phone the same amount of time.If you are on the fence about any of the Alexa devices, give yourself time to learn all she can do and to learn how she will fit into your life.  I haven't regretted my purchase.  And remember, Alexa is also learning all the time! "It's because it's a new product and the developers want the users to learn about the Echo Show's abilities" says Amazon support. Imagine if the regular Amazon Echo uttered suggestion of things to try from time to time without prompt. It would surely find it's way into the nearest closet or out on the front lawn. This device is very nice looking. I would like to keep it in my main entertainment area with a nice background, date and temp. displayed. Not a bunch of extra information clutter that Don't want. Hopefully the ability to turn off this "feature" will be added in a very near firmware update.The second burning issue is Amazon's insistence to us ing as the default and ONLY search engine that the Echo devices use. I'll pit Google against Bing in any search for a fuller more comprehensive return of information. There are a couple work around options out there but they 1. require a lot of work. 2. Require a pay account with Amazon AWS or similar. This is such a simple thing that i believe is being driven by business politics vs producing the most effective home assistance tool possible. I ended up buying an Google Home device for my general requests for information that Alexa cant handle do to it's hobbled attachment to an inferior search engine. Please Please Please allow Alexa to use other search engines, including Google, as her source for info searching.Thanks.	M. After a command like â€œAlexa, show me how to roast a duck from YouTube,â€ the screen loaded a list of YouTube videos; each video is numbered, so you could ask Alexa to play a specific clip by naming the number.You could also ask Alexa to place a call to another Echo customer. When I tried it, the Alexa app synchronized with my smartphoneâ€™s address book to determine who else was using an Echo. Then just by asking Alexa to call the name of a contact, I could immediately commence a video call.What was also nice about the Echo Showâ€™s being stationary is that it remained fixed on a flattering angle of my face. (If youâ€™re tired of staring up peopleâ€™s nostrils on FaceTime calls, youâ€™ll know what I mean.)Thereâ€™s another task that the Echo Show handled better than the Echo speaker: shopping on Amazon. By saying, for example, â€œAlexa, order me some batteries,â€ you get the screen to show a list of batteries to choose from. By contrast, with the Echo speaker, the device could only reorder batteries you had bought before â€” or, if you hadnâ€™t ordered batteries before, choose a pack of batteries for you.For audio, the Echo Show included two small stereo speakers. They sounded loud and clear but lacking in bass. Compared with fancy speakers, the Echo Show sounded average, but itâ€™s adequate for watching YouTube videos in the kitchen or streaming music if you arenâ€™t a nitpicky audiophile. B01J24C0TI	Maybe I was expecting more...	Initially I gave the Echo Show a 3 star rating. In all fairness after about 20 days of use I've decided to change my score and here's why. First off Amazon reached out to me requesting feed back and advice. I appreciate the concern and their attempts to improve the device. I've also noticed quite a few updates in the short time I've had my Show and honestly things are changing for the better. I've been updating my review and will continue to do so as I've noticed updates and get more hands on experience. After separating my expectations from the actual capabilities of this device I've come to the conclusion that the Show still had me wanting more despite it's capabilities. I currently own the original echo which is in my living room, a dot in my bedroom, and one at work. I have lights, fans, a thermostat, surround sound, and TV all connected to my Alexa devices. Of course I had to buy one with  a screen. I'm a big fan of Alexa, the products have become a routine part of my day. As soon as the Show was available to preorder I ordered one without any hesitation.Initially I wanted to put my show on a 70 inch TV stand by my 60 inch TV where my original Echo was. I figured it wouldn't look bad because I could use it as a digital picture frame also. I don't have end tables and quickly came to the realization that viewing a 7 inch screen from 8 feet away wasn't going to work for me. My Show now sits on my kitchen counter. I figured I'd get more use out of it in my living room because most of my Alexa enabled devices are in there and generally I spend more time in my living room than the kitchen. A few people mentioned why don't you put it on your desk. I honestly don't spend much time in my study, if I am at my desk I'm already on my computer and wanted the Show where I would get the most use out of it.This device was marketed as a hands free companion in the kitchen for things like recipes. My frustration is when I ask it to pull up a recipe it's inconsistent. Sometimes it wants to send the recipe to my phone, sometimes it wants me to swipe down on the screen to access the cooking directions and ingredients. Why can't I just say Alexa scroll down? Why do I have to touch the screen? Why does it have to send the recipe to my phone for me to view it when the Show already has a screen? As of now I've seen videos with CNN, Reuters, and Fox news during my flash briefings. There was a software update on 7/15/17 and now I've also seen CNBC videos. 7/19/17 I noticed today Bloomberg is now showing videos.You can display a photo, but it doesn't fill the whole screen, it has gray boarders which really make the picture look even smaller on a 7 inch screen and tacky.  The slide show feature can be set through the touch screen. Apparently this depends on how you take your pictures IE cropping and landscaping modes.Personally I think 7 inches is too small to watch a movie from any fixed location unless it was maybe a foot or two from my face so take that in to consideration when determining where you might put one. *Update* Some of Prime's videos are widescreen meaning you only get to use about half of your already small 7 inch screen to watch them. I noticed this while trying to watch 13 Hours Soldiers of Benghazi while I was cooking. This is cellphone size small.Navigating through prime videos can be a chore. You can't say the word movie, you have to say video.  When selecting options by number from the screen you have to be careful with what you say. I said something like play movie one thinking it would understand that the movie with a 1 on it would play. Instead it started playing a song. I had to say Alexa stop. And then go back through the voice navigation to Amazon Prime videos, then find my movie, then ask Alexa to play it.The problem with Youtube it pulls the most popular video that is close to your description based off of key words. It doesn't go to exactly what you are asking it to pull up. Example Alexa show me Donald Trump's latest speech on you tube. It pulled a video from May 2nd which was 2 months ago. This is because the search uses keywords in this scenario Donald Trump and Speech. Then it pulls the most popular or viewed videos.*Update* If you let it sit on the screen selection for a movie for more than a minute it will close out and take you to your home screen. This is frustrating because you have to go all the way back through the voice navigation to get back to Prime, find your movie from a selection of 3 choices per page, ask Alexa to get it to play, and if you say something wrong like Alexa play movie one you'll end up listening to music or being navigated some where else and have to start the process all over again. *Update* There are now voice tips at the bottom of the screen to help you navigate.One thing I love about my dots and the original Alexa devices is that they are intuitive I don't have to use precise wording. My Show expects me to use precise wording to navigate and use quite a bit of features. I just left the kitchen trying to get it to go to the dim screen. I used multiple variations of turn off the screen which sometimes works.I kept getting the response sorry what device? After several attempts to get this command to work I gave up and walked out of the kitchen frustrated. Maybe it's still learning from me? *Update*  I am still having issues with it not always recognizing the turn off the screen command.I also find myself constantly having to ask the Show to turn the screen off. I don't know why it keeps turning on without me using any wake words. I heard it wake when my dogs went in to the kitchen this morning 7/19/17, yet I can walk past it all day long and it doesn't wake.The show does everything you've come to love with your original echo devices, despite it's beautiful display, you'll still feel like you need a larger screen. If it was an option I'd buy one with a 10 inch screen.The sound is hands down better than any other Alexa device. The show can put out some bass. For some reason when playing Prime movies any speech sounds a bit muffled and the sound output is significantly lower..I placed an order with my Show and honestly it was fast and unlike my other Echos I could visually verify my order. I didn't have to pull my phone out, fumble with a keyboard, computer or tablet. I knew what I wanted said the name and probably in less than 30 seconds placed my order. I thought the drop in feature would be good to check in on my dogs but the camera sits high, with the Show now sitting on my kitchen counter that's not going to work. If you want to use the Show to drop in on your dogs it would have to be a foot off the ground. With just a handful of family members using the Alexa devices the video chat probably isn't going to be used much.Being able to look at my lists calendar and reminders without having to pull my phone out is nice. I wish the calendar could show more than just one day at a time. Like my whole week or month. The show won't display your whole shopping list only 3 to 4 items on the screen at one time then you have to ask it to scroll down. *Update* As of 7/16/17 the Show displays 2 days on the calendar now and will scroll through events two at a time.If you are a shopper like me that likes to browse recommendations your show will only give you a total of 12 recommendations which were no where near as accurate as my interests on my Amazon account usually are, actually they were way off. You can only view one product at a time. Basically the Show is only good for ordering when you know exactly what you want. It's not good with recommendations, and browsing items. You are limited to viewing items one at a time and then having to ask Alexa to scroll right or go right makes the process painfully slow. I guess the best way to explain the show. Most of what the Alexa devices were using your phone for can now be done on the show's touch screen. I still find myself listening to my Show more than looking at it, which kind of defeats the purpose of a screen. My biggest frustration with the Show is instead of operating Alexa from across the room with voice commands I find myself having to stand in front of it, or walk to it then hovering over it to navigate through the screens. I still find myself pulling my phone out of my pocket or reaching for a tablet to pull up information rather than getting up walking to the device and dealing with the frustratingly clunky voice navigation. Most of everything we use now a days is wireless, we aren't used to being restricted to a certain area to use a device. I haven't felt this way since the landline was the only way to make a call and there were no such things as laptops, tablets, bluetooth, smartphones and other smart devices.*Update* I attempted to use the video chat today to call my Dad. He answered with his dot so I could not see him. I thought he might answer from his phone so we could test it. The Show gives you a full screen view of yourself before the call is connected and a smaller window like Skype once the call is connected. With the angle of the camera and my Show sitting on the kitchen counter I had to take a few steps back, maybe 5 feet from the device so that my head would show up on the camera. As a note I am 6" 2. When my Dad answered we could not understand each other because of a bad connection. I ended the call quickly and called him from my cell. I have a 60 mbps connection and he uses FIOs.Why you might consider buying the Fire7 tablet before the buying the Echo ShowI bought the Fire 7 tablet with Alexa for $30.00 during Prime day, now $49.99 (Same price as a Dot!) Here are some noteworthy comparisons. The show is limited to being plugged in to a wall and although it can be easily moved it will require a little planning as to where you might put one. The Fire 7 is obviously portable and has none of these restrictions. Both have a 7-inch, 1024 x 600 touchscreen. The Show blows the Fire 7's speakers out of the water. However you can use bluetooth with the tablet and compensate for the lack of sound quality on your device. In order to use Alexa on the tablet you have to hold down the home key for a few seconds then without using the wake word Alexa or Echo speak your command. This is a nice feature because it won't wake my other Echo devices, it will also give those worried about the always listening peace of mind. Plus it's one less thing to have to say in your list of commands. I found my tablet very responsive to my commands and could do ALMOST everything my Dot and Original Echo can do EXCEPT you can not use the newly enabled voice call feature, which to me is no big deal. Apparently you can not set reminders on the Fire 7. All of my home smart devices can be controlled from my tablet by giving the same commands I use on my other Echo devices. You can not use the Show's video chat feature. Skype, Oovoo and a few other apps are options you can take advantage of. The Echo show when it displays cards and information the whole screen is filled, where as the Fire 7 you loose about 10% of the same image that is on the Show. However unlike the Show you can rotate your screen. For those that complained about the lack of HDMI output on the Show you can pick up a micro USB to HDMI adapter with the Fire 7 tablet and fix that complaint. For those that complained there was no way to cast to your TV with the Show and other Echo devices you can cast your Prime movies straight from your Fire 7 to your Firestick or Fire TV. You can access your tablet's apps via Alexa with the Fire 7, The Show has no apps. The fire 7 also syncs instantly with your other devices in Amazon's ecosystem. I find myself using my Fire7 significantly more than my Show. I don't have to be in the kitchen hovering over my counter and lets just face it even a limited Amazon tablet can do a lot more than an Echo device with a screen. Think of the Fire 7 as the budget friendly tap version of the show for $80.00 less than a tap and $180.00 less than a Show. If you are on the fence about shelling out $230.00 but want to experience the Echo screen hype this may be the way to go. B01J24C0TI	Pretty good, but rough around the edges.	I've spent the last two days with the Echo Show, and am really happy with it. I know it'll get better as time goes on, but it's a bit rough around the edges right now.* Show to Show calling is quite nice - calling across the house and to my friend's house was done flawlessly. The video was at the quality of our Skype and Facetime conversations. But backlit rooms? Forget it - it's hard to see the other person (or for them to see you.)* The display is quite nice and playing videos from Amazon Video was easy but a bit awkward. The screen is as good as the entry level Fire tablet.* Having said that, there's no skills/apps that take advantage of the screen quite yet, so it's nice to look at but not really functional quite yet. I can show my photos from my Amazon account, and manually set wallpaper from the app on the phone, but the out of box experience might let you down.* The Alexa implementation for right now is a bit weak. For example, I can't say "Alexa, play The Americans" without it going to search for music. Same with looking up Youtube. That was a bit rough.* The speakers are amazing - I was kind of surprised at how good the quality was when playing music at full volume (sorry, neighbors) with no real distortion. It's no Bose speaker but it works.* Getting this to work as my bedside alarm clock is easy - you can say "do not disturb" when you're ready for bed, and you have to set the "do not disturb" time from the app if you want it scheduled.* There is a lot of nostalgia, especially if you had a Chumby or a Sony Dash.* There's no USB ports, so you can't use this to charge your phone. Makes sense.Overall I like it - this will take the place of the bedside Echo Dot while that gets repurposed around the house. For right now, this is a fancier version of the Dot, but it will improve over time as developers take advantage of the screen, and feedback steers the development from Amazon's side. Come the holidays, this should magnitudes better. For right now, 3.5 stars. B01J24C0TI	A great addition to the Echo family!	I bought two of the Shows -- one for my daughter, one for me. It was very easy to set up, quickly letting me begin using it. I was surprised by its weight (substantial) and by its size. Even though Amazon has provided plenty of photos showing the Show in relation to other objects, it just didn't register with me that it would be as big as it is. For that reason, I'm posting two photos to show it beside other items in a typical kitchen (which is where mine is) so its easy to visualize the size.The screen is always lighted, but if you want to keep it in the bedroom, just say "Alexa, turn off your screen," and it'll go black with just a faded display of the time -- not enough light to interrupt sleep. The next time you use the wake word, the screen comes alive again. The quality of the display is impressive. The screen cycles through an array of displays urging you to interact with the Show. It gives you suggestions of things to try and displays some interesting facts and news items. I'm old school, so this is the first time I've set up a personal calendar. I've entered my upcoming appointments and I like that the cycling screens display the appointments from time to time -- helping me keep them top-o'-mind.The Show offers hands-free, video calling and messaging that's both a big convenience and a lot of fun. Speaking of videos, the cycling displays also offer videos that you can tell Alexa to play. The videos have striking clarity and quality. Viewing is comfortable and clear from several feet away. Another feature I like is that you can ask Alexa what movies are playing nearby and up pops "posters" for several. Alexa will play the trailers for you, if you ask her to.I've seen some reviews that raise objections to the Show grabbing all the contacts from your phone. I find that mysterious. All it took from my phone was my number and my daughter's. I set that up before getting the Show when I wanted to try calling/messaging with the original Echo. Maybe I did something to keep the Echo from grabbing all my contacts, but if so, I don't recall what it was.If you're on the fence, go ahead and order the Show. I'll bet you'll love it. If not, you can return it thanks to Amazon's generous return policy. B01J24C0TI	Great Device, Dodgy Privacy Issues	THE GRRRRREAT:  This is a great device, with one major privacy flaw (see THE BAD below). I've had a Sony Dash on my nightstand for years, showing me weather, time, and other things in an incredibly well-designed display (color, layout, diming at night, etc.). Sony just discontinued functionality in June 2017, so I was looking for a replacement. Just as I started my search, I mean that afternoon, presto, Amazon read my mind with a device that is about the same size and form as a Dash, but with better functionality. I love the ability of the Echo Show to play Pandora, play Amazon Prime movies, check weather, etc. And hands-free voice calling from Echo to Echo is wonderful in all ways (ease, clarity, etc.). Great job with the device Amazon!THE BAD: The main downside is the way it handles contacts, and therefore your privacy and ability to call (voice or video) with folks. In short, the Alexa App builds your contact list for this device my matching contacts from your phone with folks who also own an Echo, and it shows you them as a contact on your contact list. Unfortunately, it means it is also showing you on these folks' contact list, whether you want this or not. And you cannot edit your contact list, only block callers. What a privacy issue and awful decision by someone at Amazon! I have a number of friends who are inclined to buy this device but will NOT until this privacy issue is fixed. Fix it now, AMAZON! Then everyone will give the Echo Show 5 stars and you'll sell millions a week. If as a buyer the privacy issue does not bother you, you should buy this great device. It's wonderfully done! B01J24C0TI	A Great Addition to the Echo Family - Love It	I have multiple Echos (3 originals, several Dots and one Tap). Download updates and it is up and running.  It is the easiest device I have ever set up.  It connected instantly to my 5Ghz network and I have had zero connection problems.- All of the normal Echo functions work, but now you have video.  You can watch your timer(s) tick down; see business hours, addresses, phone numbers, etc. for businesses; watch the lyrics to songs as the play; see the 7 day weather forecast; read recipes; etc.- The screen is nice and bright and, for its size, very clear.  Not super HD, but good enough.- The touchscreen works very well.-The video calling work very well.- Streaming video works great.- Audible audiobooks play great.- The speakers are very good - far far better than the DOT and noticeably better than the original Echo.- I like the appearance.  I purchased 2 white Shows (despite the fact the Verified shows as purchasing black).  The one I set up in the kitchen blends well with my white counter surface.- Works perfectly with my TP-Link smarthome light swtiches.- The screen can be turned off so that it is completely black.  This is done in the dropdown menu under settings.- I set one of my photos as the home screen.  Again, use the settings menu.- Echo just keeps getting better and better, and this is a big advance.The Show is a great addition to the Echo family.  It does not replace the DOTs that I have hooked up to my various speakers via cable, which I prefer over Bluetooth.  Perhaps in the future it will, but the DOT is unobtrusive and relatively inexpensive so I do not care.  It could replace the original Echo, but does take up a bit more surface.  I am having a lot of fun with this.  I have had it up and running for only 24 hours so I have many other new things to try. B01J24C0TI	Some critical flaws	I loved this out of the box. The screen was crisp, and everything seemed to work OK, although I had issues getting my Phillips Hue to connect. However, there are some major issue that will likely have me returning it. The first, and most concerning, is that the camera is always on, and if you turn it off, it disables the motion sensing, so the screen always stays dim. The last thing I want on my nightstand is an internet-linked camera that could possibly be hacked. The second issue is the screen brightness. Even at the lowest setting, the screen is very bright. It lights up my bedroom. Amazon is marketing this as something you can put on your nightstand, so it's baffling that they didn't consider people wouldn't want a bright beacon on their nightstand all night. Finally, the last major flaw (or should I say irritant) is the constant clutter of "tips" scrolling across the bottom of the screen. I thought these would stop after a while, but they are a constant. I was really excited about a screen-enabled Echo, but I've gone back to the non-screen version. Also, one additional issue, while not a deal breaker, is the sound. It just doesn't sound quite as good as the original Echo, probably because the original has omni-directional speakers.	W. B01J24C0TI	Love the new Echo Show!	I have been happily anticipating the arrival of my new Echo Show. I currently own the original Echo and an Echo Dot and absolutely love them both.The Echo Show arrived nicely packaged and my first impression is that it is a clean looking design and a bit smaller than I had pictured in my mind, but that is not necessarily a bad thing, as it looks great on my counter top. It is EXTREMELY easy to set up due to the touch screen. No need to consult the Alexa app. I only needed to know the name of my Wifi, wifi password and Amazon password. This was a truly simple process and the touch screen walks you through it. It needed to update before starting, which I found odd since it was literally released today, but it only took a few minutes and we were up and running. I guess this is just an example of how Amazon is constantly updating and improving these devices.The home screen displays the time and I set it up to scroll through family pictures which I really enjoy. If you own a Kindle Fire, this has a similar pull down from the top menu to give access to your settings.I began asking Alexa questions immediately. "Alexa, how old is Tom Brady?" I got a nice picture of the golden boy along with his age which is definitely a plus. The questions are answered aloud as well as with text on the screen. You can set up a Flash Briefing using the Alexa App on your phone to tell you the news whenever you ask. CNN provided a nice video with their news which was really cool, but NPR and Wall Street Journal just had audio. I was a bit disappointed that the majority of the skills I tried did not utilize the screen. I think that just like the original Echo, this will improve with time. These are skills (apps) so it is just a matter of the skill updating to adjust to the new technology. Amazon is also great at listening to feedback and adding more features all the time. Echo Show is able to list movie times and even show movie trailers on the screen. The picture quality is very good. I also ask sports questions and the team logo, scores and information are displayed on the screen along with the answer to my question. I'm a big college sports fan and I love asking when the next game is or the score of the last game. This is a great feature.Now, what I use my Echo for the most...playing music. I am an Amazon Prime member so have access to the Prime music library. You can also use Pandora, Sirius, Spotify, Iheart radio and TuneIn. "Alexa, play Zach Brown Band."  I am amazed at the rich, full sound that fills the large kitchen/family and dining room in our open floor plan house. I am not an expert on speakers but the sound is definitely better than the original Echo which I still very much enjoy. The screen shows the lyrics so feel free to sing along!One thing that I find myself saying over and over is "Alexa go home." This seems to be the easiest way to close a skill or video and return to your home screen. You can also scroll down from the top of the screen to get your settings bar and touch the home button.YouTube is the bomb on this device. It is fully functional and will prove to be both entertaining and educational. I love this feature. "Alexa, show me a YouTube video on dog training." Boom! I have many choices available to me on the screen.  "Alexa, play number 2." Now, if I could only get Alexa to train my dog to stop putting her front paws up on the kitchen counter...I also tried the Ted Talks app and that provided audio only.Echo Show reads Audible books very well, the same as the original Echo but with the better speakers. There is not much benefit to having a screen for this, but I listen to Audible a lot while working in the kitchen or making dinner.I tested the Amazon video capabilities and was very pleased with its ability to provide that content. Since I have it on the kitchen counter, i don't plan to watch movies on the Echo Show, but certainly could if I wanted. I can unplug it and move it anywhere I would like and it quickly connects itself to Wifi once plugged in again.I looked up a recipe on the AllRecipe skill and was pleased that it showed a picture of the dish and written ingredient list along with directions on the screen. This will be quite helpful. When I played music at the same time I was looking at the recipe, it would go back to the music lyric screen after a few minutes. I would have preferred it to stay on my recipe. I will need to explore this further. It could be user error. The Campbells recipe skill does not currently provide any content on the Echo screen but sends the recipe via email to another device. I would think this can/should be improved.If you have a timer set, it is displayed on the screen. This also reverts back to the lyric screen if you are playing music, but I don't mind that as you can always ask, "Alexa, how much time is left?" and she will tell you. I just love her! The timer still goes off even with the music on.I have had this less than 24 hours but am really enjoying it. It is more user friendly than the original Echo because it is continually providing help and information on the touch screen. Even if you are technically challenged, you should be able to use this.All of the Echo devices are great for running smart home devices, but I don't currently use it for that, so can't really help you there.You can also make video calls with this, which I have not yet tried. I'm usually walking around and doing other things while talking on the phone so probably won't use this feature much. It would be great if you had children or grandchildren you wanted to see when you were out of town.In my opinion, the Echo Show is a helpful, innovative and fun gadget to own. It needs to improve a bit to fully utilize the display screen which I believe it will with time. If you currently do not have any Echo devices, then this is the one to get. If you are a bit uncomfortable with technology, then this would be a good device for you because Amazon provides so much support via the touch screen. If you already own the original Echo, you may or may not want to purchase this right now. I have not found it to be worlds better than my original Echo at this point. If you would use the video chat or are wanting a richer sound for music, then I recommend purchasing the Echo Show. I do enjoy now having an Echo in the kitchen/main part of the house and in the bedroom. I am hoping that, like the original Echo, the content will continue to improve with time, but I am very happy with my purchase of the Echo Show. I hope this helped you! B01J24C0TI	Alexa Needs a Face	The Show just may be my favorite Echo product yet. I unpacked it just under 24 hours ago, and had the day off to get acquainted with it. The speaker system is just as good as the original Echo, plus on many tracks, synced lyrics are shown. Stories span the screen throughout the day, and you have the option to tap the screen to see a video of the story. The first one I saw was of a spider casting a 50 foot web.The time is displayed unless you're in the middle of another task, so when I'm in the room with the show, I don't have to ask the time. The screen also gives real time outdoor temperature. Some Networks offer a video option to the Flash Briefing. Also today, I discovered that my favorite News Network, OANN, has an app that allows me to listen to their Newscast live, which is great.I have yet to try making or receiving video calls, as it appears none of my contacts have even the Alexa APP. The home screen has a scrolling wallpaper effect, and you can also customize it. I've got a lot of discovering to do yet with the Show, but it is a welcome edition to my collection of Alexa Enabled Devices.Only suggestion I have so far would be that, given the Show does have a screen and a motion sensor, Alexa be given a virtual face for active conversations. I'm no programmer, but with the sensor, Alexa should even be able to follow the user, turning her head as whoever is talking to her moves....One week later... The Echo Show has yet to disappoint. Over the past few days I've had the opportunity to try the Video Calling and Drop-in features. They work great, and it was pretty cool to be away from home and drop-in on my Echo Show, seeing that all was just as I had left it. Now I just need to convince other people I know to al least install the Alexa App. The coolest part is that as long as you have Wi-Fi, your phone doesn't need to have a service plan, as calls are placed via the Alexa App. I installed a Google Voice # on an old phone of mine, installed the Alexa App under a separate Amazon account, and am now able to make calls with that phone to and from my current phone and Echo devices. Going back to the Drop-In feature now, I believe a great addition to that would be what I consider a "Show-Me" feature. Using "Show-Me" would enable the user to access the camera-feed of the Echo Show from their phone or another Echo Show, without the screen waking up. Renters have to deal with Landlords who sometimes allow their workers into the premises unbeknownst to  the renter. The ability to watch your home, without someone who lives there knowing you are watching, via your Echo Show through your Smart phone, would be awesome.A few other features I have stumbled across are that, beyond the camera/mic off button, the camera can be turned off separately using the "Do Not Disturb" feature. Either ask Alexa, use the pull down menu on-screen, or use the Alexa App to accomplish this. While "Do Not Disturb" is active, the "Drop-In" feature is disabled. Also, tell Alexa to "Turn off your screen" will stop the advertisements from scrolling across the screen and leave only a clock, which moves every few minutes. The illumination of the clock is controlled via the bright/dim feature on the pull down menu.2nd Edit: Going back to the "Show Me" feature that I think would be quite helpful (not that I'd expect that's what it would be called), it seems that since the Echo Show does have a motion sensor, that would be quite useful in a private Drop-In security feature. Assuming there is no one home, and no pets are in the house, one should theoretically be able to set an alert, based on the motion sensor, that will instantly notify the Smart phone of the primary user, or any household member selected, that something is happening that should not be. That notification, once received, could allow the respondent to give their Smart phone a command such as "Alexa, Show Me", and immediately see what is happening while the Show remains silent, while in no way alerting any potential intruder, except perhaps, Alexa's eventual face staring them down. Then, if needed, the user could call the police and give the intruder a welcoming farewell surprise. The Echo Show could potentially be the perfect silent alarm, giving one the option to see what's happening before the police are called for what could possibly be no reason at all. Makes me wish computer programming made any sense whatsoever to me.Something else I recently discovered is that while the Alexa App on your Smart phone will import any contacts who also have the Alexa App on their Smart phone, you do have the option of blocking any of them whom you do not wish to communicate with via the Alexa App. The App is also helpful in giving yourself a reminder when get home. Just send yourself a text or voice message through the App if you have something you may need to take care of but may forget otherwise. The yellow lights will be active on the Echo, and the Show will have the number of messages illuminated in the conversation symbol.	tLeander7	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A3T011GYG597CW/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	17	5	2017/06/29

B01J24C0TI	Best Echo available!	The Amazon Echo Show is a voice-activated device. You can instruct it to play video content, play music, stream online audio, order products and services, and control home automation products. The Echo Show is the first device of its kind to feature its own screen, which in my opinion, greatly enhances the use and potential of this device.Iâ€™ve been using this device for a few days so far. Below you will find some of my initial impressions:### What I Like ######Good build quality: The Show has a nice, bright screen that has good viewing angles.Good sound: The speakers on the Show sound much better than the original echo.Easy setup: Setup was extremely easy, mostly due to the Showâ€™s touch screen. After making a few selections, the Show was up and running in no time.Content suggestions: When you aren't interacting with the Show, it continuously displays content suggestions. I like that it will suggest videos to watch.Video content: I like being able to view Amazon Video, video news briefings, movie trailers, and YouTube videos on the Show.Video calling: Video calling works as advertised. I like being able to initiate a call with my voice.Music with lyrics: When playing songs from Amazon Music, you can see album art and song lyrics on the screen.Home automation: Like other Echos, the Show can control your smart home products. The show has the extra ability to display camera feeds.On-screen apps: The echo can display my calendar, reminders, lists, timers, local weather, and more. Because of this, I find the Show infinitely more useful than the original Echo.### What I Don't Like ######The Show needs more functionality that leverages the touch screen. I trust that new skills will be added over time but I'm disappointed that more wasn't available at launch.The Show should have an audio-out port.I wish the Show could have a bigger screen option, a video-out port, and/or video casting capability.The show should not be used as an alarm clock at this point. There's no backup battery solution at the moment. The display currently is too bright for a dark room.The angle of display and the camera cannot be adjusted.None of the Echos can answer all of the questions the Google Home can answer.None of the Echos can cast video to a TV like the Google Home can.The Echo Show is not cheap.### How will I use the Echo Show ######- Playing Music from Amazon Music- Watching videos from YouTube- Controlling home automation products and displaying camera feeds# # # Bottom Line # # # # # #The Echo Show is the best Echo available. It's also the best voice activated device available. The addition of the screen makes it infinitely better than any of the other options.While display and touch specific functionality is limited at the moment, we can trust that both Amazon and 3rd party developers will add new functionality over time.If you find the Show's price to be too high, the Echo Dot is still a great device. It's also not an expensive investment, should you decide to replace it with an Echo Show later.# # # Echo Show vs Echo # # # # # #If you are trying to decide between the Echo and the Echo Show, get the Show. You'll get better audio plus the potential for much greater functionality via the touch screen,# # # Echo Show vs Google Home # # # # # #If you want to cast video and audio, Google Home is the better choice since none of the Echos can do this.  Other than that, I recommend the Echo Show over the Google Home because it has more skills and it has a screen.Yes, the Google Home can answer more complex questions. I just think people will use these devices more for consuming content and controlling smart home products than they will use them to ask complex questions.I own both devices so I have the best of both worlds.# # # Suggested Improvements # # # # # #Add a physical home button and back button on the device and on a compatible remoteAdd a camera that can pan and zoom and track faces that are talking.Add an audio-out port.Add a separate alarm clock module that is resistant to downtime related to software patching, software crashes, network outages, etc.Provide a option for displaying video on a bigger screen via a video-out port, video casting, or bigger Echo Shows.Add the ability to customize the home page with custom apps, custom news feeds, social media feeds, etc.Add the ability to do image searches and 3D images searchesAbility to display my commute route using google maps, with trafficAdd Skype support and allow voice initiated calls.Add the ability to stream live TV from a cable box, TIVO, or the internet.Add official apps for SiriusXM, Netflix, Hulu, and YouTube. The YouTube app show allow you to log in and verbally access your playlists, history, subscribed channels, etc.	Quentin Moore	Color: Black|Configuration: Echo Show	B01J24C0TI	/gp/pdp/profile/A1HIVLFS0H3QG0/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	312	5	2017/06/29
B01J24C0TI	Amazon fan, hugely dissapointed!!	So I ordered 2 of these and neither worked properly. They both had connectivity issues with my network and kept dropping out. I have plenty of wifi networks to choose from in my house and these devices didn't work properly on any. I am extremely disappointed as I was really looking forward to adding these to my home automation setup. Currently I have 6 echo devices, 2 of which I have installed in cars. Those all have worked flawlessly so I don't know how they could screw this up.Device #1.  The setup was easy and it connected to my 5Ghz network no problem at first. I tested various commands on it and even dropped in on a couple of my rooms. But then I tried the video chat. It worked for about the first minute then started to drop out and finally quit. I tried a few more voice commands then suddenly it just stopped answering me and the yellow connection bar appeared on the bottom.This device also seemed to struggle with the spatial separation with the with the other Echos in the house and would never over ride them. So to test is I had  to disable all other Echo devices in earshot.So I reset device #1 to the factory settings and tried again on a different network. This time a 2.4 ghz.  Once setup, the results were exactly the same.So I was hoping this might just be this device, so I opened box #2.Device #2. I setup this one as instructed, and again the setup was easy and had no problems. I skipped passed the intro video as I had already seen it several times at this point. Then when I tried to give a voice command, it did not respond at all. I could not get it to do one thing I asked. I checked the mic and made sure it was on and nothing was obstructing it. But still nothing. By this point I am about an hour into setup and I am giving up. I tried a video call with the device and the connection was just horrible.So I felt I had enough and packed it all away to be sent back. I thought about asking for a replacement, but thought that since I just bought 2 of them, what were the chances that a 3rd would work. Given my experience with Amazon products this far, I had high hopes for this product. But I have never been let down so much.Other issues that slightly bothered me were, the in ability to change the camera angle. I wanted to put on in my kids room, so I could drop in on them and tell them to come down stairs, or give them instructions. But unfortunately, all I really saw was the upper half of their room and none of the floor. My oldest is barely 4' so this didn't help.The next thing was an audio out port. This was a major drawback for me on the first Echo. I had to crack it open and wire up and audio out port. Fortunately, the Dot fixed this issue. So why wouldn't they just throw all the best desired features into this one is beyond me.So, needless to  say I am returning. I hope that what ever the issue was, Amazon is able to resolve it. I would still love to see the next version of this.As for tech support, I tried emailing the comments and tech link Amazon sent in an email to me, but their server kept kicking it back to me. So, hopefully they will see this and get back to me through here. I hope others have a much better experience, as I really hope a product like this takes off. B01J24C0TI	Alexa Showing Off With The Show.	Received my Echo Show yesterday as promised (overnight shipping); but I did not unpack and set it up until today. Once you are connected to your Wi-Fi network, the Echo Show goes through a software update and optimizes itself. This took about 10 minutes. After this it is time to explore what this device can do.On the home screen you will see your local time and temp. Every few seconds the screen will change, and you will be show different "Try" phrases for Alexa to do.Within minutes I was listening to one of my Pandora stations. I am a music lover and the sound from the Show does not disappoint. If you are expecting a concert from this device, you will be disappointed. My Show sits on my computer desk, and the sound is more than adequate.The screen is only 7 inches, which is plenty big for a device that will sit on a counter, stand of some kind. I read reviews from tech sites in the days before the release of this product and they were somewhat positive, but many mentioned they didn't care for the angle the screen stood at. As it sits on my desk, it is a few inches below my straight line of sight, which is perfect for me personally.I have not set the Echo Show up to communicate with other Shows, but I will in the coming days. Once I have explored more of what you can do, and watch a couple of Amazon original shows and watch a few You Tube videos, I will come back and update.If you don't have an echo already, this is the perfect time to get onboard. As a result, the waist goes super high, higher than in the photo. It is a solid inch to two inches above my belly button. For me, this is great. It bothers me to feel constricted or pinched, and the tall waistband sits comfortably in the narrow part of my waist. I wear looser shirts with my yoga pants instead of tank tops, so this has not affected my fashion style in any way.Second, the material is not the smooth & shiny yoga pant material I'm used to. It's sort of like a mix between cotton yoga pants and shiny yoga pants. This is fine with me; the only downside is that the pants do tend to pick up lint and little pieces of whatever a lot easier than normal pants and I need to pat down my butt every time I stand up to make sure I'm not carrying around carpet fuzz or something.So why did I give this 5 stars? Because these arrived about two weeks ago and I have literally worn them every single day, all day, and they are still comfortably snug instead of stretched out, they feel great, and they look presentable enough to wear out of the house on an errand or to grab a bite.For sizing/dimensions: I am a 5'11" woman who weighs about 145-150lbs, which is a normal weight for my height (I'm thin in a "fit" way, versus in a "skinny" way). I bought XL size, and probably could have pulled off a Large, however I really dislike being squeezed into clothing in any way. The crop goes the perfect halfway distance between my knee and my ankle. The bottom part of the pants is a little loose on my calves, although not in a way which is noticeable to other people.If I'm being honest with you, Amazon Review friends, I will probably end up buying another two pairs of these to fulfill my lifelong attempt to avoid wearing real pants. I would not recommend them for hiking because there isn't very much traction and I had to be really careful on slick rocks and on ice. B06W9LJ6W7	Super cute, but needs some modification to be comfortable	These are super cute and a little less casual than regular Toms, which is what I wanted. I ordered my normal size of 8.5. Also of note, I have very wide feet so a lot of "normal" shoes are way too tight for me. Regular Toms usually fit me right out of the box and are pretty much the only closed shoe I can wear all day without being uncomfortable.The lace material does not stretch as well as regular Toms and there is a very spiky/scratchy seam on the inside right where it hits the side of your foot. It was so bad it actually cut up my foot the first day I wore it. There is almost no give the first time you put the shoes on, but they seem to stretch out with time (though much more slowly than regular Toms).To solve the spiky seam problem, I cut a small piece of black grosgrain ribbon and super glued it right over the seam. So far, it has been worlds better. I'm happy because these are more work-appropriate than regular Toms, and I'm hoping they will continue to get more comfortable as I wear them. Before I applied the ribbon, however, they were unwearable for me because the spiky fabric poking into my foot was too painful.	JR	Size: 8.5 B(M) US|Color: Black	B00THLG0FW	/gp/pdp/profile/A2AR5SPZDGKTT4/ref=cm_cr_arp_d_pdp?ie=UTF8	1	4	2016/03/31

B06W9LJ6W7	I love everything about these shoes except that they don't have ...	I love everything about these shoes except that they don't have great, lasting arch support. Initially the shoes feel good, but eventually (at least if you wear them everywhere, all the time like I did) the arch support starts to flatten down and becomes less supportive. That said, I highly recommend TOM's shoes for comfort and ease, and for quick coordination with other things in your wardrobe. If I didn't live in such a rainy part of the country I would probably wear these everyday, but canvas is not ideal for slogging through constant rain puddles. B06W9LJ6W7	One for one = One size for each foot	I ordered a size 11, which is my normal size in this brand. My natural size runs around 10.5, and I recommend ordering up to the next whole size for Toms for anyone in a similar in-between situation. Unboxing, this pair initially appeared fine. The color "light grey" was as expected. Both soles said '11'. However, the left shoe seemed unnaturally tight when I tried them on. Being my third pair of Toms, I was surprised. Upon closer inspection, the left shoe was actually a '10' - confirmed by the inner tag. I doubt Tom intended one for one to mean one size for each foot, but that's what I got. Needless to say, if you're questioning the fit, check both sets of tags (insoles and inner arch). Under regular circumstances, you can't go wrong with Toms Classics. They are ultra comfortable and do shape to your foot after a few wears... provided you get two of the same size.	B. B06W9LJ6W7	Toms Cares About Philanthropy	For these particular shoes, I probably should have gone a half size up from my usual shoe size, as they were a tiny bit snug. Perhaps, since they are canvas, they will stretch out a bit after wearing. I was trying to replace a pair of beloved black canvas slip-ons that I had worn to pieces. The thing that really attracted me to the company, though, was their one for one deal. For every pair of shoes you buy from them, a person in need gets a pair of shoes. The price of the light canvas shoes I purchased was a little high for what they were, but when you consider that you are really paying for two pairs of shoes, it was well worth it. Someone who needs shoes will get a pair. It was easy to do, and I would recommend them highly. B072JTFZLY	Excellent shoes for weightlifting	I LOVE these shoes. First of all, I purchased them fro weightlifting. Converse all-stars seem to be the go-to shoe for most weightlifters, but they are far too narrow for me. I don't usually buy wide width, but Converse are really narrow. These shoes fit perfectly; they are very comfortable. They have the flat non-compressible sole that I was looking for. Not only that, but I noticed that the converse that I tried had some sort of felt on the bottom (so they don't squeak, maybe?) which made them slide on hard flooring. In contrast, the Vans have a rubber bottom that gets great traction. B072JTFZLY	BUYER BEWARE!!	I was shocked at how poor the quality was. I have been wearing Vans since 1995, and have been a loyal customer due to the high quality. After seeing these shoes I was ready to write Vans off as another company that squandered quality for profit, but instead, I decided to take the shoes I received and travel an hour away to an authorized Vans retail location at which I was able to compare the shoes I received to the same model and size they had in stock. After comparing several features, it was determined that the shoes I received were "knock-off" faux Vans. Fakes. Not real.... the bar code on the box was even bogus. If you receive these shoes, and the quality seems lacking, I would recommend going to an authorized Vans retailer, and comparing. The shoes I received felt like they would fall apart after several months of wear, whereas the shoes I replaced them with from the Vans store feel like they'll last years. Buyer beware!!!	Megan M. B072JTFZLY	Great shoes as long as you add your own insoles for arch support	I love these shoes for the way they look and generally fit.
